column4: positioned along the Corellian Trade Spine hyperlane. A world of varied terrain including mountains
column5: forests
column6: plains
column7: and the infamous Agrilat Swamp
column8: Corsin has earned galactic renown as the premier destination for swoop racing enthusiasts and professional racers.\n\nThe planet's most distinctive feature is its swoop racing culture
column9: which has dominated Corsin's economy and identity for centuries. The Agrilat Swamp Circuit
column10: carved through the treacherous wetlands surrounding the capital city of Cuipernam
column11: represents one of the most dangerous and prestigious racing venues in the galaxy. The circuit's combination of natural obstacles
column12: unpredictable terrain
column13: and high-speed straightaways has made it a proving ground for the galaxy's most skilled swoop pilots.\n\nSwoop racing on Corsin evolved from local competitions into a massive commercial enterprise that attracts millions of spectators annually. The planet's economy revolves almost entirely around the racing industry
column14: with hotels
column15: casinos
column16: repair facilities
column17: and entertainment venues catering to racers and fans from across the galaxy. Corsin's races are broadcast throughout known space
column18: with successful racers achieving celebrity status and lucrative sponsorship deals.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column19: Corsin maintained membership in the Galactic Republic while developing its unique racing culture. The planet's strategic location along the Corellian Trade Spine ensured steady traffic of traders and travelers
column20: many of whom stopped to witness the famous races.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column21: Corsin became contested territory. Approximately two years into the conflict
column22: Separatist forces invaded the planet
column23: recognizing its strategic position along the Corellian Trade Spine. The Battle of Corsin saw Republic clone troopers
column24: supported by Jedi Generals
column25: fighting to liberate the world from Separatist occupation. The battle proved costly for both sides
column26: with fighting damaging portions of the racing circuits and surrounding infrastructure.\n\nThe Republic ultimately reclaimed Corsin
column27: though the occupation left scars on the planet's economy and racing industry. Many facilities required extensive repairs
column28: and the death toll among both military forces and civilian population affected the close-knit racing community.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column29: Corsin came under Imperial control. The Empire maintained a presence on the planet to ensure order and collect taxes from the lucrative racing industry
column30: though Imperial authorities showed little interest in suppressing the swoop races themselves. The Empire recognized that the races served as entertainment that helped keep populations distracted from political matters.\n\nImperial oversight brought some changes to Corsin's racing culture. New safety regulations were implemented
column31: though these were often ignored by racers and organizers alike. The Empire also used the high-profile races as opportunities for propaganda
column32: with Imperial officials appearing at major events and Imperial sponsorship of certain racing teams.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column33: Corsin remained under Imperial control for most of the conflict. The planet's focus on entertainment and its distance from major military objectives meant it avoided becoming a major battleground
column34: though Imperial garrison forces maintained security throughout the war.\n\nThe swoop racing continued throughout the Galactic Civil War
column35: with racers from various backgrounds competing regardless of political affiliations. The races provided one of the few neutral grounds where beings from different factions could gather
column36: united by their love of high-speed competition. Some Rebel sympathizers used the large crowds and busy spaceports as cover for covert activities
column37: though most visitors came simply to watch the races.\n\nThe Agrilat Swamp Circuit maintained its reputation as the galaxy's most challenging track
column38: with its combination of natural hazards
column39: sharp turns
column40: and treacherous conditions claiming numerous racers over the years. Despite the dangers
column41: or perhaps because of them
column42: the circuit remained the ultimate test of swoop racing skill.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column43: Corsin's status as a racing world ensured its continued prosperity drawing the attention of both the New Republic and Corporate Sector Authority."

Text: "Coruscant is an ecumenopolis in the Coruscant system of the Core Worlds. Coruscant was also known as 'Imperial City' under the Galactic Empire
column4: and 'New Republic City' under the New Republic.\n\nFamous for its cosmopolitan culture and towering skyscrapers
column5: Coruscant's population consists of trillions of citizens hailing from a vast array of both humanoid and alien species.\n\nThough debated by historians
column6: it is generally believed that Coruscant was the original homeworld of humanity."

Text: "Coruscant is a planet located in the Coruscant system of the Core Worlds region
column4: positioned at the intersection of numerous major hyperspace routes including the Corellian Run and the Perlemian Trade Route. This strategic location has made Coruscant the political
column5: economic
column6: and cultural heart of galactic civilization for over 25
column7: 000 years.\n\nCoruscant is an ecumenopolis - a planet-wide city - with virtually every square meter covered by towering skyscrapers and sprawling urban infrastructure. The endless cityscape is home to trillions of beings
column8: making it the most populous world in known space. The upper levels house the wealthy elite and government
column9: while the lower levels are dangerous slums where sunlight never reaches and criminal organizations operate freely.\n\nThough debated by historians
column10: Coruscant is believed to be humanity's original homeworld. The planet was one of the Core Founders of the Galactic Republic
column11: established approximately 25
column12: 000 years before the Battle of Yavin
column13: and served as the Republic's capital throughout its history.\n\nThe Jedi Temple
column14: built upon an ancient Sith shrine
column15: housed the Jedi Archives and served as the Order's headquarters. The Senate Building's massive rotunda hosted thousands of senators debating legislation and shaping galactic civilization. These structures became symbols of the Republic's ideals of peace and democracy.\n\nDuring the final decades of the Republic
column16: corruption and gridlock paralyzed the Senate. Chancellor Palpatine rose to power promising reform. During the Clone Wars
column17: Coruscant served as the Republic's command center. The Battle of Coruscant near war's end saw one of the largest space battles in history
column18: culminating in Anakin Skywalker and Obi-Wan Kenobi rescuing the kidnapped Chancellor from General Grievous.\n\nFollowing Order 66
column19: Coruscant became capital of the Galactic Empire. Palpatine transformed it into Imperial City
column20: converting the Jedi Temple into the Imperial Palace. The planet underwent significant changes under Imperial rule
column21: with stark Imperial architecture replacing elegant Republic designs. The Senate was eventually dissolved
column22: and the population swelled with Imperial bureaucrats and military personnel.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column23: Coruscant remained the heavily fortified heart of the Empire
column24: protected by massive defenses. The lower levels became increasingly lawless
column25: with criminal organizations like Black Sun expanding operations. Despite the oppressive Imperial presence
column26: resistance movements operated underground
column27: providing intelligence to the Rebel Alliance.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor
column28: Coruscant remained under Imperial control for several years as warlords competed for dominance. Approximately six years after Endor
column29: the New Republic launched a campaign to liberate the capital. The battle proved to be one of the most significant post-Endor engagements.\n\nThe New Republic's capture of Coruscant marked a major turning point. The planet was renamed New Republic City and again became capital of a democratic government. The Imperial Palace was converted to government offices
column30: and the Senate was reestablished.\n\nThe transition proved challenging
column31: with millions of former Imperial personnel and divided loyalties. The lower levels remained largely ungoverned
column32: with criminal organizations continuing their operations. Despite these challenges
column33: Coruscant's liberation represented hope for restoring democracy and justice to the galaxy."

Text: "Crustai is the second planet of the Crustai system in the Unknown Regions."
"Crustai is a terrestrial planet located in the Crustai system of the Unknown Regions. A remote
column4: mysterious world far beyond the borders of known space
column5: Crustai remained largely unknown to the Galactic Republic and most galactic governments throughout history.\n\nLittle is known about this world due to its extreme isolation in the Unknown Regions. The treacherous and unmapped hyperspace routes that characterize this region of space made exploration dangerous and unpredictable
column6: with few vessels venturing into the area and even fewer returning with reliable data.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column7: Crustai's existence was barely recorded in Republic star charts. The planet's remote location meant it remained unexplored and uncolonized
column8: with no known contact between its inhabitants (if any existed) and the broader galactic community.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars and the subsequent rise of the Galactic Empire
column9: Crustai continued its isolation in the Unknown Regions
column10: untouched by the conflicts that engulfed much of known space.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column11: Crustai remained one of countless worlds in the Unknown Regions that lay beyond the reach of most galactic governments. Serving as a only minor waystation for Imperial remnant forces
column12: it leaves most of its mysteries waiting to be discovered by future explorers brave enough to venture into the uncharted depths of space."

Text: "Daalang is a world on the Gamor Run in the Mid Rim
column4: near Attahox."

Text: "Daalang is a terrestrial planet located in the Mid Rim
column4: positioned along the Gamor Run hyperlane near Attahox. The world features varied terrain including plains
column5: forests
column6: and urban centers
column7: with a temperate climate suitable for habitation.\n\nDaalang is home to a diverse population
column8: including the native Daal species
column9: a reptilian humanoid race known for their craftsmanship and technical skills. The planet developed a modest industrial base
column10: with local factories producing machinery
column11: starship components
column12: and consumer goods for regional markets.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column13: Daalang maintained membership in the Galactic Republic
column14: though its remote location kept it largely isolated from major political affairs. The planet's economy relied on manufacturing and trade along the Gamor Run
column15: serving as a waypoint for merchants and travelers moving through the Mid Rim.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column16: Daalang remained officially neutral
column17: though its industrial capacity made it a target of interest for both the Republic and the Separatists. The planet avoided major battles
column18: with local authorities working to preserve autonomy and protect their manufacturing sector from outside interference.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column19: Daalang came under Imperial control. The Empire established a presence on the planet to oversee production and ensure compliance with Imperial regulations
column20: though Daalang retained some local governance due to its limited strategic value. The planet's factories continued to operate
column21: supplying equipment and components to Imperial markets while maintaining regional trade.\n\nDaalang's population adapted to changing galactic governments
column22: focusing on industry and commerce while avoiding involvement in larger conflicts. The planet remained a minor but stable manufacturing center in the Mid Rim
column23: with its inhabitants falling under the umbrella of the newly emboldended Hutt Cartel."

Text: "Dagobah is a remote
column4: unexplored planet in the Dagobah system
column5: and one of the purest places in the galaxy within the Force. A remote world of swamps and forests
column6: it served as a refuge for Jedi Grand Master Yoda during his exile after the destruction of the Jedi Order."

Text: "Dagobah is a remote
column4: swamp-covered planet located in the Sluis sector of the Outer Rim Territories. Shrouded in mist and perpetually dark beneath its dense canopy
column5: Dagobah is one of the purest places in the galaxy within the Force
column6: though it also harbors a cave strong in the dark side.\n\nThe planet's surface is almost entirely covered in fetid swamps
column7: bogs
column8: and twisted forests of gnarltree and other vegetation. Dense fog blankets the landscape
column9: and the atmosphere is thick and humid. Dagobah's ecosystem is populated by numerous creatures including bogwings
column10: butcherbugs
column11: dragonsnakes
column12: and vine snakes
column13: though no sapient species are native to the world.\n\nDagobah remained largely unknown and unexplored throughout galactic history. Its location was not recorded in most astrogation charts
column14: and the planet's murky atmosphere interfered with sensors
column15: making it difficult to detect from space. This isolation made Dagobah an ideal refuge for those seeking to hide from the galaxy.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column16: a vergence in the Force existed on Dagobah. A battle between a powerful Jedi and a dark sider resulted in the dark warrior's death within a cave
column17: which became saturated with dark side energy and remained so for millennia afterward. This dark side cave would later serve as a test for Luke Skywalker.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column18: Jedi Master Yoda experienced a Force vision on Dagobah during his investigation into the origins of the inhibitor chips implanted in the clone troopers. However
column19: he did not remain on the planet at that time.\n\nFollowing the execution of Order 66 and the fall of the Jedi Order
column20: Yoda fled into exile. The ancient Jedi Master chose Dagobah as his hiding place
column21: precisely because of its isolation and its strong connection to the Force
column22: which helped mask his presence from the Emperor and Darth Vader. Yoda constructed a simple mud hut near the dark side cave and lived there in solitude for nearly two decades.\n\nDuring his exile
column23: Yoda waited for the day when he could train a new generation of Jedi. That day came when Luke Skywalker
column24: following the guidance of Obi-Wan Kenobi's spirit
column25: crashed his X-wing in Dagobah's swamps while searching for the legendary Jedi Master. Initially appearing as a simple
column26: eccentric creature
column27: Yoda tested Luke's patience and character before revealing his true identity and agreeing to train him in the ways of the Force.\n\nYoda trained Luke in the fundamentals of Jedi philosophy and Force techniques
column28: though Luke's training was interrupted when he sensed his friends in danger on Cloud City. Despite Yoda's warnings
column29: Luke departed to help them
column30: leaving his training incomplete.\n\nLuke returned to Dagobah to complete his training
column31: only to find Yoda dying of old age at approximately 900 years old. With his final words
column32: Yoda confirmed that Darth Vader was indeed Luke's father and revealed that there was ""another Skywalker."" After Yoda's death
column33: his body disappeared as he became one with the Force
column34: leaving only his simple robes behind.\n\nFollowing Yoda's passing
column35: Dagobah returned to its state of isolation
column36: the mud hut slowly being reclaimed by the swamp. The dark side cave remained
column37: a lasting testament to an ancient conflict
column38: while the planet itself stood as a monument to one of the greatest Jedi Masters who had ever lived."

Text: "Dantooine is a planet located in the Raioballo sector's Dantooine system of the Outer Rim Territories' northern New Territories region
column4: near the Sinsang and Angor systems. It is the fourth planet in orbit of its sun Dina
column5: and have two moons."

Text: "Dantooine is a pleasant world of grasslands
column4: rivers and small forests located in the Raioballo sector of the Outer Rim Territories. A peaceful agricultural planet
column5: Dantooine is home to simple farming communities and is largely ignored by the greater galaxy due to its lack of strategic importance or valuable resources.\n\nThe planet's surface consists of vast savannas dotted with sparse forests and numerous ruins dating back thousands of years. Ancient Jedi training grounds and temples can be found scattered across the landscape
column6: remnants of a time when the Jedi Order maintained a significant presence on the world. The mild climate and fertile soil make Dantooine ideal for agriculture
column7: with the colonists growing grains and raising livestock.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column8: Dantooine served as the location of a Jedi Enclave
column9: a training center established far from the Core Worlds to provide a peaceful environment for Jedi students. During the Mandalorian Wars and subsequent Jedi Civil War
column10: the enclave became a focal point of conflict. The Sith Lord Darth Malak bombed the enclave from orbit
column11: believing it housed a Star Map that could lead to the ancient Rakatan space station known as the Star Forge.\n\nFollowing the destruction of the Jedi Enclave
column12: Dantooine fell into obscurity once more. The planet was slowly recolonized over the following millennia
column13: with settlers establishing small farming communities among the ancient ruins. The colonists maintained a simple existence
column14: largely isolated from galactic politics and conflict.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column15: Dantooine remained neutral and saw little military activity due to its remote location and lack of strategic value. The scattered farming settlements continued their quiet existence
column16: far removed from the battles that engulfed much of the galaxy.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column17: Dantooine's isolation could not protect it from Imperial attention. When the Rebel Alliance established a base on the planet
column18: the Empire discovered its location. Princess Leia Organa
column19: under interrogation aboard the Death Star
column20: falsely claimed that the Rebel base was still on Dantooine in an attempt to save Alderaan. Grand Moff Tarkin ordered the planet destroyed anyway to demonstrate the Death Star's power
column21: but upon arrival
column22: Imperial forces found only the abandoned Rebel base. The planet was spared destruction
column23: though an Imperial garrison was established to prevent the Rebellion from returning.\n\nAfter the Battle of Yavin
column24: Dantooine remained under Imperial control
column25: with garrison forces stationed at the former Rebel base site. The Empire maintained only minimal presence
column26: as the planet's agricultural economy and scattered population posed no significant threat.\n\nFollowing the Battle of Endor and the fragmentation of Imperial authority
column27: Dantooine still remained under the thumb of Imperial remnant forces. The planet's ruins attracted archaeologists and historians seeking to learn more about the ancient Jedi Order
column28: while the farming communities continued their traditional way of life
column29: content to remain on the fringes of galactic civilization."

Text: "Darkknell is an astronomical object located in the Darkknell system of the galaxy's Outer Rim Territories
column4: situated along the Hydian Way at grid coordinates M-17."

Text: "Darkknell is a terrestrial planet in the Outer Rim
column4: located along the Hydian Way hyperlane. A heavily industrialized world known for its sprawling urban centers and manufacturing facilities
column5: Darkknell has long been a strategic location for galactic powers due to its position on a major trade route.\n\nThe planet's surface is dominated by factories
column6: warehouses
column7: and dense metropolitan areas
column8: with pollution from centuries of industrial activity creating a perpetual haze over many regions. Despite its grim appearance
column9: Darkknell maintains a thriving economy based on manufacturing and trade.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column10: Darkknell's strategic location made it a contested world between Republic and Separatist forces. The planet changed hands multiple times during the conflict
column11: with both sides seeking to control its industrial capacity and its position along the Hydian Way.\n\nUnder the Galactic Empire
column12: Darkknell became an important industrial center
column13: its factories producing military equipment and supplies for the Imperial war machine. The Empire maintained a strong garrison on the planet to ensure continued production and to suppress any resistance movements among the local population."

Text: "The Dathomir system in the Quelli sector contains planet Dathomir. Despite the presence of numerous predator species
column4: a few thousand Human and Zabrak colonists call this place their home
column5: even though the hostile environment hardened most of them."

Text: "Dathomir is a remote
column4: mysterious planet located in the Quelli sector of the Outer Rim Territories. A world of dense forests
column5: rocky mountains
column6: and wild grasslands
column7: Dathomir is home to numerous dangerous predator species and a harsh
column8: unforgiving environment.\n\nThe planet is perhaps best known as the homeworld of the Force-sensitive Witches of Dathomir
column9: divided into various clans including the Nightsisters who practice the dark side. These matriarchal societies have developed unique Force traditions separate from both the Jedi and Sith
column10: using techniques they call ""magicks"" to control and manipulate the Force in ways unfamiliar to the wider galaxy.\n\nDathomir's ecology includes rancors
column11: which the Witches have learned to tame and ride
column12: as well as countless other dangerous creatures lurking in the planet's wilderness. The males of the human population
column13: called Nightbrothers
column14: live separately from the female-dominated clans in a tribal warrior culture.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column15: Dathomir was home to ancient civilizations
column16: though much of this history has been lost to time. The planet remained isolated from the galactic community for much of its history
column17: with its inhabitants developing independently.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column18: the planet drew the attention of Count Dooku and the Confederacy of Independent Systems
column19: who sought to exploit the dark side powers of the Nightsisters. This led to conflict between the Nightsisters and the Separatists
column20: resulting in the near-annihilation of the Nightsister clan by General Grievous and his droid army.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column21: Dathomir fell under nominal Imperial control. However
column22: the planet's remote location and hostile environment meant the Empire maintained only minimal oversight. Some Imperial attention was drawn to Dathomir due to rumors of Force-sensitive inhabitants
column23: though most expeditions to the planet ended in failure.\n\nDespite the hostile environment
column24: a few thousand human and Zabrak colonists managed to establish settlements on Dathomir
column25: though the planet's dangerous wildlife and harsh conditions hardened most of them into fierce survivors."

Text: "Dellalt is an astronomical object located within the Tion Cluster of the regions known as the Outer Rim Territories and the Slice. The astronomical object is positioned within grid square T-6 on the Standard Galactic Grid."
"Dellalt is a remote agricultural world located in the Tion Cluster of the Outer Rim Territories. A planet of varied terrain including plains
column4: forests
column5: mountains
column6: and seas
column7: Dellalt remained largely isolated from galactic affairs for much of its history.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column8: Dellalt was part of the ancient kingdom ruled by the legendary warlord Xim the Despot. Xim used Dellalt as a repository for his vast war treasures
column9: constructing hidden vaults deep beneath the planet's surface. After Xim's defeat at the Third Battle of Vontor
column10: the location of these treasure vaults was lost to history
column11: though rumors of their existence persisted for millennia.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column12: Dellalt was settled by human colonists who established small farming communities. The planet's economy remained primarily agricultural
column13: with most inhabitants living simple lives far removed from the political intrigues of the Core Worlds. The remote location and lack of strategic resources meant Dellalt attracted little attention from galactic governments or major corporations.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column14: Dellalt maintained its isolation
column15: avoiding involvement in the conflict between the Republic and the Separatists. The planet's distance from major hyperspace routes and limited industrial capacity made it an unlikely target for either side.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column16: Dellalt fell under nominal Imperial authority
column17: though the Empire maintained only a minimal presence due to the planet's peripheral location and limited value. The Corporate Sector Authority
column18: which controlled much of the surrounding region
column19: showed some interest in Dellalt but never established significant operations there.\n\nShortly before the Battle of Yavin
column20: the legendary smuggler Han Solo and his Wookiee companion Chewbacca became involved in a search for Xim's lost treasures on Dellalt. Their expedition led them into conflict with various treasure hunters and the Corporate Sector Authority
column21: ultimately discovering one of Xim's ancient vaults. However
column22: the treasures proved less valuable than expected
column23: and Dellalt returned to its quiet existence.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor
column24: Dellalt remained a backwater world
column25: its inhabitants continuing their agricultural traditions while the galaxy underwent dramatic political changes around them."

Text: "Delrakkin is the only planet in the Delrakkin system capable of sustaining life. Home to the reptilian Delrakkin
column4: the world is covered with mountain ranges and jungles
column5: as well as a perpetual cloud cover that provide it with incessant storms and rain."

Text: "Delrakkin is a remote terrestrial planet located in the Outer Rim Territories. The sole inhabited world in the Delrakkin system
column4: this planet is home to the reptilian Delrakkin species
column5: who evolved in the planet's harsh environment of perpetual storms and dense jungles.\n\nThe planet's surface is dominated by towering mountain ranges and thick jungle canopy
column6: shrouded beneath heavy cloud cover that produces constant rainfall and violent electrical storms. This challenging climate shaped the Delrakkin into a hardy and resourceful species
column7: well-adapted to their world's extreme conditions.\n\nDelrakkin remained isolated from the broader galactic community for much of its history
column8: with the planet's harsh weather and remote location discouraging exploration and colonization attempts. The Delrakkin developed their own unique civilization in relative isolation
column9: building their settlements within the mountains and jungle valleys where they could find shelter from the worst of the storms.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column10: Delrakkin was discovered by explorers but attracted little interest due to its inhospitable environment and lack of obvious strategic or economic value. The planet maintained minimal contact with the galactic community
column11: with the Delrakkin occasionally venturing off-world as traders or explorers
column12: though most remained on their homeworld.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column13: Delrakkin's isolation spared it from the conflict between the Republic and the Separatists. The planet remained neutral
column14: with its inhabitants focused on their own affairs rather than the galactic struggles that engulfed so many other worlds.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column15: Delrakkin fell under nominal Imperial control
column16: though the Empire showed little interest in the planet beyond ensuring basic compliance with Imperial law. The harsh environment and limited resources meant that Imperial presence remained minimal
column17: with local Delrakkin authorities retaining considerable autonomy in managing planetary affairs.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column18: Delrakkin remained under loose Imperial oversight
column19: though the planet saw little direct involvement in the conflict. Its remote location and challenging environment meant that neither the Empire nor the Rebel Alliance devoted significant attention to the world.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor
column20: Delrakkin's status became uncertain as various Imperial remnant factions and the New Republic competed for influence in the Outer Rim territories."

Text: "Denon
column4: a planet located between Osarian and Nubia
column5: is an ecumenopolis world
column6: with city growth covering the entire surface
column7: similar to Coruscant."

Text: "Denon is a planet located in the Inner Rim Territories
column4: positioned between Osarian and Nubia along the Corellian Trade Spine. An ecumenopolis world with city growth covering the entire surface similar to Coruscant
column5: Denon is one of the most heavily urbanized planets in the galaxy.\n\nThe planet serves as a major hub for commerce
column6: entertainment
column7: and information distribution. Denon is home to numerous corporate headquarters
column8: including those of some of the galaxy's largest media conglomerates and financial institutions. The planet's towering skyscrapers and endless cityscape are illuminated by perpetual artificial lighting.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column9: Denon remained loyal to the Republic despite its strategic importance. Under the Galactic Empire
column10: the planet became a center for Imperial propaganda and surveillance operations
column11: with the Empire maintaining a significant security presence to monitor the flow of information throughout the Core Worlds.\n\nDenon's economy is primarily service-based
column12: with billions of inhabitants working in media production
column13: financial services
column14: and administrative roles for galactic corporations. The planet imports most of its food and raw materials from agricultural worlds throughout the Inner Rim."

Text: "Dola"
"Dolla"
"Dolla is an astronomical object located in the regions known as the Outer Rim Territories and the Western Reaches. It is situate in grid square L-18 of the Standard Galactic Grid."

column4: positioned in grid square L-18 of the Standard Galactic Grid. A world of modest resources and limited strategic value
column5: Dolla remained largely isolated from major galactic affairs throughout most of its recorded history.\n\nThe planet's surface features varied terrain including plains
column6: forests
column7: and scattered mountain ranges
column8: with a climate suitable for human habitation. Dolla developed a small population centered around agriculture and light manufacturing
column9: maintaining a quiet existence far from the political intrigues of the Core Worlds.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column10: Dolla was discovered by early explorers but attracted little attention due to its remote location and lack of valuable resources. The planet maintained minimal contact with the broader galactic community
column11: with most inhabitants living simple
column12: agrarian lives largely independent of Republic governance.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column13: Dolla's isolation spared it from the conflict between the Republic and the Separatists. The planet remained neutral
column14: avoiding entanglement in the galactic struggle that engulfed so many other worlds.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column15: Dolla fell under nominal Imperial control
column16: though the Empire maintained only a minimal presence due to the planet's peripheral location and limited value. Local authorities retained considerable autonomy in managing day-to-day affairs
column17: with Imperial oversight limited to ensuring basic compliance with Imperial regulations.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column18: Dolla remained under loose Imperial authority
column19: though the planet saw little direct involvement in the conflict. Its remote location and lack of strategic importance meant that neither the Empire nor the Rebel Alliance devoted significant resources to controlling the world.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the fragmentation of Imperial authority
column20: Dolla's status became uncertain as various Imperial remnant factions and the New Republic competed for influence in the Outer Rim territories."

Text: "Dorin is a planet located in the galaxy's Expansion Region that is the homeworld of the Kel Dor species. Its Dorin gas and helium-rich environment meant that they are forced to rely on rebreathers to survive off-world
column4: as oxygen is deadly to them."

Text: "Dorin is a planet located in the Expansion Region of the galaxy
column4: positioned along the Hydian Way hyperlane. The homeworld of the Kel Dor species
column5: Dorin is a world unlike most others in the galaxy
column6: with an atmosphere composed primarily of helium and a unique gas called Dorin gas
column7: which is toxic to most other species but essential for Kel Dor survival.\n\nThe planet's unusual atmospheric composition means that Kel Dor must wear specialized antiox breath masks and protective goggles when traveling off-world
column8: as oxygen-rich environments are deadly to them. This biological requirement has made the Kel Dor one of the most distinctive species in the galaxy.\n\nDorin's surface features varied terrain including mountains
column9: forests
column10: and plains
column11: though much of the world remains shrouded in the planet's thick atmosphere. The Kel Dor developed a highly spiritual and philosophical society
column12: with strong emphasis on justice and moral behavior. Their culture places great importance on family bonds and community cooperation.\n\nThe Kel Dor joined the Galactic Republic thousands of years before the rise of the Empire
column13: becoming valued members of galactic civilization. Their natural aptitude for moral reasoning and justice made many Kel Dor ideal candidates for the Jedi Order. The Jedi Master Plo Koon
column14: one of the most respected members of the Jedi High Council during the final years of the Republic
column15: was perhaps the most famous Kel Dor in galactic history.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column16: Dorin remained loyal to the Republic. The planet contributed to the war effort
column17: with Kel Dor serving in both the Jedi Order and the Grand Army of the Republic. The Kel Dor's strong sense of justice made them natural opponents of the Separatist cause.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire and the execution of Order 66
column18: Dorin fell under Imperial control. The Empire maintained oversight of the planet
column19: though the Kel Dor's unique atmospheric requirements and relatively isolated location meant direct Imperial interference remained limited. Many Kel Dor
column20: following their species' strong moral convictions
column21: secretly sympathized with or actively supported the Rebel Alliance.\n\nThe Baran Do Sages
column22: an ancient Kel Dor order of Force-sensitives predating the Jedi by thousands of years
column23: continued to practice their traditions in secret during the Imperial era
column24: preserving Kel Dor Force traditions that might otherwise have been lost."

Text: "D'Qar is a verdant planet located in the Ileenium system of the Outer Rim Territories."
"D'Qar is a verdant planet located in the Ileenium system of the Outer Rim Territories
column4: positioned in the Western Reaches. A lush
column5: forested world with varied terrain including mountains
column6: valleys
column7: and clear skies
column8: D'Qar remained largely unexplored and uninhabited throughout most of galactic history due to its remote location and lack of strategic resources.\n\nThe planet's surface is dominated by dense forests and rugged mountain ranges
column9: with numerous valleys and clearings scattered throughout the landscape. D'Qar's temperate climate and abundant water sources support a diverse ecosystem
column10: though the world never developed any native sentient species. The planet's isolation from major hyperspace routes meant that few explorers or colonists ventured to this distant world.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column11: D'Qar was briefly notable as the site of an ancient Massassi temple. The Massassi
column12: a fierce warrior species enslaved by the Sith
column13: constructed several temples across various worlds in the Outer Rim. The temple on D'Qar
column14: built in the distinctive pyramidal style characteristic of Massassi architecture
column15: served an unknown purpose before being abandoned. Over millennia
column16: the structure fell into ruin
column17: gradually being reclaimed by the surrounding jungle.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column18: D'Qar remained uncharted and forgotten
column19: its location known only through fragmentary ancient records that few scholars bothered to investigate. The planet's lack of valuable resources and its distance from established trade routes meant it attracted no colonization efforts or commercial interest.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column20: D'Qar's isolation kept it completely removed from the conflict between the Galactic Republic and the Confederacy of Independent Systems. The planet remained undisturbed
column21: its forests and ancient ruins untouched by the warfare that consumed much of the galaxy.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column22: D'Qar continued its existence in obscurity. Imperial star charts may have included the Ileenium system
column23: but the Empire showed no interest in establishing a presence on the remote
column24: resource-poor world. The planet's ancient Massassi temple remained hidden beneath jungle growth
column25: unknown to Imperial surveyors.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column26: D'Qar's extreme isolation meant it played no role in the conflict between the Empire and the Rebel Alliance. Neither side had reason to venture to the distant world
column27: and it remained one of countless unexplored planets in the vast Outer Rim.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column28: D'Qar maintained its status as an uncharted
column29: uninhabited world. The New Republic's focus on rebuilding galactic civilization and defending against Imperial remnants meant that remote planets like D'Qar received little attention. The ancient Massassi ruins continued to slowly crumble beneath the encroaching forest
column30: while the planet itself remained pristine and undisturbed.\n\nD'Qar's isolation and the natural concealment provided by its dense forests would later make it attractive to organizations seeking to operate away from the scrutiny of galactic governments. The ruins of the ancient Massassi temple
column31: though in a state of significant decay
column32: still stood as a testament to a forgotten era of galactic history
column33: waiting to be rediscovered by future explorers."

Text: "Dromund Kaas is the third planet in the Dromund system
column4: a star system in the Sith Worlds region of the Outer Rim Territories's Esstran sector."

Text: "Dromund Kaas is a dark
column4: forbidding world shrouded in perpetual storms and lightning
column5: located in the Sith Worlds region of the Outer Rim Territories. Once the thriving capital of the ancient Sith Empire
column6: this planet served as the seat of power for the Dark Council and the Sith Emperor for over a millennium.\n\nThe planet's surface is covered in dense jungles teeming with dangerous predators mutated by dark side energies. The Imperial Citadel
column7: an imposing fortress-temple
column8: dominates the landscape of Kaas City
column9: the planet's primary settlement. Below the city lie ancient Sith ruins and tombs
column10: repositories of forbidden knowledge and dark side artifacts.\n\nDuring the Great Galactic War and subsequent Cold War
column11: Dromund Kaas remained hidden from the Republic
column12: serving as the beating heart of the resurgent Sith Empire. The planet's dark side nexus grew stronger over the centuries
column13: fed by Sith rituals and the suffering of countless slaves.\n\nThough the Sith Empire eventually fell and the planet was abandoned
column14: Dromund Kaas remains saturated with dark side energy.\n\nIts ruins continue to attract treasure hunters
column15: dark side cultists
column16: and those seeking forgotten Sith secrets
column17: despite the inherent dangers of the world's hostile environment and lingering dark presence."

Text: "Eadu is a storm-stricken planet in the Outer Rim Territories. It hosted the Eadu Energy Conversion Laboratory prior to the outbreak of the Galactic Civil War
column4: where Galen Erso and his team of scientists attempted to unlock the secrets of the kyber crystals as part of the Death Star project."

Text: "Eadu is a remote
column4: mountainous planet located in the Outer Rim Territories
column5: shrouded in perpetual storms and lashing rain. The planet's rugged terrain consists of towering rocky peaks and deep valleys
column6: with constant electrical storms that make navigation treacherous. The harsh environment kept Eadu largely isolated from galactic civilization for much of its history.\n\nDuring the early years of the Galactic Empire
column7: the planet was selected as the site for a top-secret Imperial research facility known as the Eadu Energy Conversion Laboratory. The remote location and hostile weather conditions made it ideal for concealing sensitive projects from prying eyes.\n\nThe facility was placed under the direction of scientist Galen Erso
column8: who had been coerced into Imperial service by Director Orson Krennic. Erso and his team of researchers worked on unlocking the properties of kyber crystals
column9: massive quantities of which were needed to power the Empire's ultimate weapon
column10: the Death Star. The laboratory's energy conversion research was crucial to developing the superlaser that would become the battle station's primary weapon.\n\nThe installation consisted of multiple platforms built into the mountainsides
column11: connected by landing pads capable of receiving Imperial cargo shuttles. Despite the Empire's efforts at secrecy
column12: Rebel intelligence eventually discovered the facility's existence and its connection to the Death Star project.\n\nShortly before the Battle of Yavin
column13: a Rebel strike team led by Cassian Andor infiltrated Eadu during a violent storm. The mission resulted in the facility being bombed by Rebel starfighters
column14: causing massive explosions that destroyed much of the installation. Galen Erso was mortally wounded during the attack
column15: dying in the arms of his daughter
column16: Jyn Erso
column17: who had accompanied the strike team.\n\nFollowing the facility's destruction
column18: Eadu returned to obscurity
column19: its ruined platforms standing as a testament to the Empire's ruthless pursuit of ultimate power and the sacrifices made by those who opposed it."

Text: "Eriadu is the primary world in the Seswenna sector
column4: and one of the Outer Rim's most active trade centres. It sit on the intersection of several hyperspace routes
column5: including the Rimma Trade Route
column6: the Hydian Way
column7: the Lipsec Run
column8: and the Yankirk Route."

Text: "Eriadu is a terrestrial planet located in the Seswenna sector of the Outer Rim Territories
column4: positioned at the strategic intersection of multiple major hyperspace routes including the Rimma Trade Route
column5: the Hydian Way
column6: the Lipsec Run
column7: and the Yankirk Route. This convergence of trade lanes has made Eriadu one of the most important commercial and industrial centers in the Outer Rim for millennia.\n\nThe planet's surface features varied terrain including mountains
column8: forests
column9: and plains
column10: though much of the world has been heavily industrialized. Eriadu's economy is dominated by manufacturing
column11: with massive factories producing everything from starship components to weapons systems. The planet's shipyards
column12: while smaller than those of Kuat or Corellia
column13: maintain a reputation for quality construction.\n\nEriadu was discovered early in the Old Republic's expansion into the Outer Rim and quickly became a regional power due to its strategic location. The planet developed a highly stratified society
column14: with wealthy industrial families controlling much of the planet's economy and politics. The Tarkin family rose to become one of Eriadu's most powerful dynasties
column15: with their influence extending throughout the Seswenna sector.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column16: Eriadu remained loyal to the Republic and served as an important military staging point for operations in the Outer Rim. The planet's industrial capacity contributed significantly to the Republic's war effort
column17: producing military equipment and supplies.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column18: Eriadu's importance only increased. The planet became the sector capital and Governor Wilhuff Tarkin
column19: a native of Eriadu
column20: rose to become one of the Empire's most powerful figures. Under Imperial rule
column21: Eriadu's factories were pressed into service producing military hardware for the Imperial war machine
column22: with production quotas enforced by garrison troops.\n\nThe Empire maintained a strong military presence on Eriadu throughout the Galactic Civil War
column23: using the planet as a regional command center and supply depot. The planet's strategic position made it vital for Imperial operations throughout the Outer Rim.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column24: Eriadu hosted the Eriadu Conference
column25: a meeting of Imperial Moffs that was disrupted by a Rebel attack.\n\nFollowing the Battle of Endor and the Emperor's death
column26: Eriadu remained under Imperial control as various warlords and Imperial remnant factions competed for dominance in the Outer Rim."

Text: "Empress Teta
column4: once known as Koros and also called Cinnagar (after its capital city) is a city-world in the Deep Core. An ecumenopolis to rival Coruscant
column5: Empress Teta is the hub of galactic civilisation in that region
column6: and one of the few worlds that could be reached from outside the Deep Core. It is a major supplier of carbonite to the galaxy
column7: which makes it a center of interest and power for the Mining Guild
column8: which controls it in all but name. First colonised by slower-than-light generation ships in the millennia before the founding of the Galactic Republic
column9: Empress Teta has had a tumultuous history
column10: from the Krath Holy Crusade into the Clone Wars
column11: where its control by the Mining Guild led to it joining the Confederacy of Independent Systems. During the age of the Galactic Empire
column12: Empress Teta was a security checkpoint into the Deep Core."

Text: "Empress Teta
column4: originally known as Koros
column5: is a city-covered planet located in the Deep Core region of the galaxy. The world is renowned for its ecumenopolis surface
column6: with the capital city Cinnagar serving as the political and cultural heart of the system. Empress Teta is one of the few Deep Core worlds accessible via stable hyperspace routes
column7: making it a major hub for trade and travel in the region.\n\nThe planet was first settled by generation ships thousands of years before the founding of the Galactic Republic. The Koros system was unified under the rule of Empress Teta
column8: who led a campaign to bring peace and prosperity to the region. Her reign marked the beginning of the planet's rise as a center of civilization and commerce.\n\nDuring the Great Hyperspace War
column9: Empress Teta played a pivotal role as a battleground between the Sith Empire and the forces of the Republic. The planet was invaded by Sith forces led by Naga Sadow
column10: but the defenders
column11: including Jedi and local military
column12: ultimately repelled the attack
column13: preserving the system's independence.\n\nCenturies later
column14: Empress Teta became the birthplace of the Krath
column15: a dark side cult founded by Satal Keto and Aleema Keto. The Krath seized control of the planet and launched the Krath Holy Crusade
column16: challenging both the Jedi Order and the Galactic Republic. The conflict saw significant battles on Empress Teta
column17: including the involvement of Ulic Qel-Droma and Exar Kun during the Great Sith War.\n\nThroughout the Old Republic era
column18: Empress Teta remained a major urban and industrial center
column19: known for its production of carbonite and other valuable resources. The planet's strategic location and economic importance made it a frequent target for political intrigue and military campaigns.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column20: Empress Teta joined the Confederacy of Independent Systems
column21: influenced by the Mining Guild and local interests. The planet's industrial capacity was leveraged to support the Separatist war effort
column22: though it saw limited direct conflict compared to other Core Worlds.\n\nUnder the Galactic Empire
column23: Empress Teta served as a security checkpoint for travel into the Deep Core. The planet maintained its status as a commercial and urban hub
column24: with Imperial authorities overseeing trade and industry while allowing local governance to continue.\n\nBy the time of the New Republic
column25: Empress Teta remained a significant world in the Deep Core
column26: known for its rich history
column27: urban sprawl
column28: and role as a gateway to the region. Its legacy as a center of culture
column29: commerce
column30: and conflict continues to shape its identity in the galaxy."

Text: "Enarc is a planet in the Mid Rim. Located at the intersection of multiple hyperspace routes
column4: it is a prosperous trade world and distribution center. Once a regional headquarters for the Trade Federation
column5: it served as a staging point for the fleet of warships that blockaded Naboo
column6: a decade before the Clone Wars. Following the rise of the Galactic Empire
column7: Enarc was Imperialized
column8: and transformed into an Imperial Army transport and supply depot."

Text: "Enarc is a terrestrial planet located in the Kira system of the Borderland Regions in the Outer Rim Territories. A world of varied terrain including plains
column4: forests
column5: and urban centers
column6: Enarc developed into a significant commercial hub due to its strategic position at the intersection of multiple hyperspace routes including the Kira Run.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column7: Enarc was discovered during the early expansion of the Galactic Republic. The planet joined the Republic and developed steadily over millennia
column8: establishing itself as a regional trade center. Its location made it valuable for merchants and shipping companies moving goods between different regions of the Outer Rim.\n\nDuring the final decades of the Galactic Republic
column9: Enarc came under the influence of the Trade Federation
column10: one of the galaxy's most powerful commercial organizations. The Trade Federation established a significant presence on the planet
column11: using it as a regional headquarters and staging point for their commercial fleet operations. The planet's strategic location and developed infrastructure made it ideal for coordinating Trade Federation activities throughout the surrounding sectors.\n\nApproximately 32 years before the rise of the Empire
column12: the Trade Federation used Enarc as a staging area when assembling the fleet that would blockade and invade Naboo. The massive concentration of Trade Federation battleships and support vessels at Enarc went largely unnoticed by Republic authorities
column13: demonstrating both the Federation's power and the Republic's inability to effectively monitor corporate military buildups.\n\nFollowing the failed invasion of Naboo
column14: the Trade Federation maintained its operations on Enarc despite increased Republic scrutiny. When Count Dooku founded the Confederacy of Independent Systems a decade later
column15: the Trade Federation joined the Separatist movement
column16: and Enarc became part of Separatist-controlled space.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column17: Enarc served as an important logistics hub for Separatist forces operating in the Outer Rim. The planet's infrastructure
column18: built up by the Trade Federation over decades
column19: proved valuable for coordinating military operations and managing supply lines. Republic forces launched several campaigns to contest control of Enarc
column20: recognizing its strategic importance.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire and the end of the Clone Wars
column21: Enarc came under Imperial control. The Empire recognized the planet's value as a logistics center and moved quickly to seize Trade Federation assets and infrastructure. Imperial authorities reorganized Enarc's facilities
column22: transforming the former Trade Federation headquarters into an Imperial Army transport and supply depot.\n\nUnder Imperial rule
column23: Enarc became a major military logistics hub for operations in the Outer Rim. The Empire established extensive warehouses
column24: vehicle depots
column25: and troop barracks across the planet's surface. Imperial Army units used Enarc as a staging point before deployment to conflict zones
column26: while supply convoys regularly departed from the planet carrying equipment and provisions to Imperial garrisons throughout the region.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column27: Enarc remained under firm Imperial control due to its strategic importance. The Empire maintained a substantial garrison to protect the valuable supply depot and ensure the continued flow of military equipment to Imperial forces throughout the Outer Rim. The planet's role as a transport hub made it a tempting target for Rebel operations
column28: though the strong Imperial presence deterred direct attacks.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the Emperor's death
column29: Enarc's status became contested as various Imperial remnant factions and the New Republic competed for control of strategic logistics centers in the Outer Rim. The planet's warehouses and transport infrastructure made it a valuable prize
column30: with multiple factions recognizing that controlling Enarc would significantly enhance their ability to supply and deploy forces throughout the region."

Text: "Endor is a forested moon in the Outer Rim. Home to a variety of species
column4: including the predatory Ewoks
column5: it has been a relatively isolated section of the galaxy for thousands of years. However
column6: it is also known for the many shipwrecks that have crashed there over the millennia. The Empire used Endor as the construction site for the second Death Star
column7: and installed a shield generator on the surface to protect the battlestation. Four years after the destruction of the first Death Star
column8: the Rebel Alliance engaged the Imperial Navy in the Battle of Endor
column9: destroying the Death Star and killing the Emperor."

Text: "Endor
column4: also known as the ""sanctuary moon
column5: is a small forested moon orbiting the gas giant Endor in the Moddell sector of the Outer Rim Territories. The moon's surface is covered in dense temperate forests
column6: featuring towering trees
column7: ferns
column8: and varied terrain including plains
column9: savannas
column10: deserts
column11: and mountain ranges. Despite its remote location
column12: Endor harbors a remarkably diverse ecosystem.\n\nThe moon is home to numerous species
column13: most notably the Ewoks
column14: small furry bipeds who live in primitive tribal villages built high in the forest canopy. Despite their diminutive size and Stone Age technology
column15: the Ewoks are intelligent
column16: resourceful
column17: and fiercely protective of their forest home. Other native species include the hulking gorax
column18: spotted pony-like bordoks which Ewoks use as mounts
column19: and various predators lurking in the wilderness.\n\nFor thousands of years
column20: Endor remained largely isolated from galactic civilization. Its remote location and lack of obvious resources meant few explorers ventured to the moon
column21: though occasional starships crashed on its surface over the millennia
column22: leaving behind wreckage scattered throughout the forests. Some of these ancient crash sites became sacred places or sources of salvaged technology for the native Ewoks.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column23: the Empire selected Endor as the construction site for the second Death Star. The moon's isolation made it ideal for concealing the massive project from Rebel intelligence. Imperial engineers constructed a sophisticated SLD-26 planetary shield generator on Endor's surface
column24: protected by a substantial garrison of Imperial troops including scout troopers and AT-ST walkers. This shield projected a protective field around the incomplete Death Star in orbit
column25: making the battle station invulnerable to direct attack.\n\nApproximately four years after the Battle of Yavin and the destruction of the first Death Star
column26: Rebel intelligence discovered the second Death Star's location above Endor. The Alliance planned a two-pronged assault: a commando team would infiltrate the forest moon to disable the shield generator while the Rebel fleet attacked the Death Star directly.\n\nThe strike team
column27: led by General Han Solo and including Princess Leia Organa
column28: Chewbacca
column29: and Luke Skywalker
column30: arrived on Endor aboard a stolen Imperial shuttle. Shortly after landing
column31: they encountered the Ewoks. Initial contact proved tense
column32: with the primitives nearly cooking several team members before C-3PO convinced them the Rebels were allies by recounting stories of their struggles against the Empire.\n\nThe Ewoks
column33: led by Chief Chirpa
column34: agreed to help the Rebels after learning of the Empire's presence on their moon. When the strike team attempted to infiltrate the shield generator bunker
column35: they were captured by Imperial forces who had been expecting them
column36: having been lured into a trap as part of Emperor Palpatine's plan to destroy the Rebellion.\n\nHowever
column37: the Ewoks launched a surprise attack on the Imperial garrison
column38: using their knowledge of the forest terrain and primitive but effective weapons and tactics. Despite suffering casualties from Imperial firepower
column39: the Ewoks' guerrilla warfare proved remarkably effective. They destroyed several AT-ST walkers using logs
column40: rocks
column41: and other improvised weapons
column42: and their superior mobility in the forest environment allowed them to outmaneuver the Imperial forces.\n\nThe Ewok assault created enough chaos for the Rebel commandos to break free and seize control of the shield generator facility. Han Solo's team successfully destroyed the generator
column43: bringing down the protective shield around the Death Star. This allowed the Rebel fleet
column44: engaged in desperate space battle above
column45: to launch their assault run into the Death Star's superstructure.\n\nIn orbit
column46: Admiral Ackbar's fleet engaged the Imperial Navy while Lando Calrissian and Wedge Antilles led starfighters into the Death Star's incomplete sections. Simultaneously
column47: aboard the battle station
column48: Luke Skywalker confronted Darth Vader and Emperor Palpatine. In the throne room
column49: Vader ultimately turned against his master to save his son
column50: hurling Palpatine down a reactor shaft. The Emperor's death and Vader's redemption fulfilled the prophecy of the Chosen One bringing balance to the Force.\n\nLando and Wedge successfully fired proton torpedoes into the Death Star's main reactor
column51: triggering a chain reaction. The massive battle station exploded in a spectacular fireball visible from Endor's surface
column52: marking the Empire's greatest defeat and the beginning of its eventual collapse.\n\nFollowing the battle
column53: the Ewoks celebrated with the Rebels in their treetop villages
column54: honoring the heroes who had helped liberate their moon from Imperial occupation. The destruction of the Death Star and the Emperor's death sent shockwaves throughout the galaxy
column55: inspiring hope in oppressed populations and emboldening resistance movements across countless worlds.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor
column56: the moon became a symbol of the Rebellion's triumph and the turning point in the Galactic Civil War. Debris from the destroyed Death Star remained in orbit and scattered across Endor's surface
column57: including fragments that would be salvaged or studied in subsequent years.\n\nThe New Republic established a small observational presence in the Endor system
column58: though they largely left the Ewoks to govern themselves. The primitive species had proven their worth as warriors and allies
column59: earning the respect of the galactic community. Some Ewoks maintained contact with their Rebel friends
column60: while others returned to their traditional way of life in the forest canopy
column61: content to live as their ancestors had for generations."

Text: "Esfandia is a small proto-planet in Wild Space. Once it orbited a star
column4: but has since broken away and beome a rogue planet. Esfandia is one of the few worlds that housed a HoloNet Relay that could reach into the Unknown Regions."

Text: "Esfandia is a remote ice planet located in Wild Space
column4: positioned along the border between the known galaxy and the Unknown Regions. A frozen world perpetually shrouded in blizzards and ice storms
column5: Esfandia's surface is covered in vast glaciers
column6: frozen tundra
column7: and jagged ice formations that create a harsh and inhospitable environment.\n\nDespite its extreme conditions
column8: Esfandia is home to several native species that have adapted to the planet's frozen climate. The most notable of these are the Lugubraa
column9: a peaceful sentient species whose culture centers around artistic expression and communal living within ice caves carved into the planet's glaciers. The Lugubraa developed a sophisticated society despite their isolation
column10: creating intricate ice sculptures and maintaining oral traditions passed down through countless generations.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column11: Esfandia was discovered by Republic explorers charting Wild Space. The planet's extreme environment and remote location meant it attracted little colonization
column12: though the Republic recognized its potential strategic value due to its position near the Unknown Regions.\n\nThe Galactic Republic established a HoloNet relay station on Esfandia
column13: recognizing that the planet's location made it ideal for extending communications into previously unreachable regions of space. This relay represented one of the Republic's most remote communications outposts
column14: allowing limited HoloNet coverage to extend beyond the traditional boundaries of known space. The installation required specialized equipment to function in Esfandia's harsh climate
column15: with most of the facility constructed beneath the ice to protect it from the planet's violent storms.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column16: Esfandia remained a quiet backwater world
column17: its HoloNet relay maintained by a small contingent of Republic technicians who lived in isolation from the rest of the galaxy. The native Lugubraa maintained peaceful relations with these offworlders
column18: occasionally trading with them but generally keeping to their traditional way of life deep within their ice caves.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column19: Esfandia's isolation spared it from direct involvement in the conflict between the Republic and the Confederacy of Independent Systems. The planet continued its quiet existence
column20: with the HoloNet relay continuing to operate and extend communications into Wild Space and beyond.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column21: Esfandia came under Imperial authority. The Empire recognized the strategic value of the planet's HoloNet relay and maintained the installation
column22: using it to monitor communications in the Unknown Regions and track potential threats from beyond known space. Imperial personnel replaced Republic technicians
column23: though the harsh conditions meant the garrison remained small.\n\nApproximately three years after the Battle of Yavin
column24: Esfandia became the site of a significant engagement during the Galactic Civil War. The Empire
column25: seeking to develop new weapons technology
column26: established a secret research facility on the planet to work on advanced shield systems and other military projects. The isolation and harsh environment made Esfandia an ideal location for such classified work.\n\nRebel Alliance intelligence discovered the Imperial research facility and launched an operation to investigate its activities. The mission brought Rebel operatives into contact with both Imperial forces and the native Lugubraa
column27: whose peaceful existence was being disrupted by the Imperial presence and the military operations occurring on their world.\n\nThe engagement on Esfandia highlighted the planet's vulnerability despite its remote location. The battle saw fighting across the frozen surface as Rebel and Imperial forces clashed
column28: with the harsh environment proving as dangerous as enemy fire. The native Lugubraa
column29: caught in the crossfire of galactic conflict
column30: suffered casualties despite their attempts to remain neutral.\n\nFollowing the battle
column31: the Empire maintained its presence on Esfandia
column32: though on a reduced scale. The HoloNet relay continued to operate throughout the Galactic Civil War
column33: providing the Empire with communications coverage into the Unknown Regions. The research facility's status following the engagement remained classified
column34: though Imperial authorities increased security measures to prevent future Rebel incursions.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the Emperor's death
column35: Imperial control over Esfandia weakened as forces were recalled to defend Core Imperial territories. The HoloNet relay became contested
column36: with both Imperial remnants and the New Republic recognizing its strategic value for extending communications into Wild Space and the Unknown Regions.\n\nThe native Lugubraa
column37: having endured years of occupation and conflict
column38: worked to rebuild their communities and return to their traditional way of life. The ice caves that had sheltered their civilization for millennia continued to provide refuge
column39: though the scars of war and Imperial exploitation would take generations to fully heal."

Text: "Exodeen is a planet in the Colonies region
column4: along the Hydian Way trade route. One of the earliest-occupied planets along the route
column5: Exodeen was a loyal member of the Galactic Republic until the rise of the Empire. Its native Exodeenians could be found in both Imperial bureaucracy and within the Rebel Alliance."

Text: "Exodeen is a terrestrial planet located in the Colonies region of the galaxy
column4: positioned along the Hydian Way hyperlane. One of the earliest worlds colonized along this vital trade route
column5: Exodeen developed into a significant commercial and cultural center during the Old Republic era.\n\nThe planet is home to the native Exodeenian species
column6: a humanoid race known for their adaptability and strong sense of civic duty. Exodeenian society placed great emphasis on education
column7: public service
column8: and participation in galactic affairs. Their culture produced many skilled administrators
column9: diplomats
column10: and military officers who served throughout the galaxy.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column11: Exodeen was among the first worlds colonized along the Hydian Way during the Republic's early expansion. The planet quickly became an important waypoint for trade and travel
column12: benefiting from its strategic position along one of the galaxy's busiest hyperspace routes. Exodeen joined the Galactic Republic as a founding member and maintained unwavering loyalty for over 25
column13: 000 years.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column14: Exodeen flourished as a center of commerce and culture. The planet's cities featured impressive architecture blending traditional Exodeenian design with influences from across the galaxy. Educational institutions on Exodeen earned reputations for excellence
column15: producing graduates who went on to serve in the Republic's diplomatic corps
column16: military
column17: and administrative bureaucracy.\n\nExodeenians became known throughout the galaxy for their reliability and dedication to public service. Many left their homeworld to pursue careers in Republic government
column18: with Exodeenian senators
column19: ambassadors
column20: and civil servants playing important roles in galactic governance. This tradition of service became deeply ingrained in Exodeenian culture
column21: with families taking pride in members who distinguished themselves in Republic service.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column22: Exodeen remained steadfastly loyal to the Galactic Republic. The planet contributed both resources and personnel to the war effort
column23: with many Exodeenians serving in the Grand Army of the Republic and in various administrative capacities supporting the military campaign against the Separatists. The planet's position along the Hydian Way made it valuable for Republic logistics and supply lines.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column24: Exodeen came under Imperial control. The transition from Republic to Empire proved deeply troubling for many Exodeenians
column25: whose cultural values emphasized democratic participation and civic responsibility. However
column26: the planet's long tradition of government service meant that many Exodeenians found themselves serving the new regime
column27: often in the same bureaucratic positions they had held under the Republic.\n\nExodeenian administrators
column28: diplomats
column29: and military officers became fixtures within Imperial bureaucracy. Their reputation for competence and reliability ensured they remained valued by Imperial authorities
column30: even as many privately harbored doubts about the Empire's authoritarian policies. Some Exodeenians embraced the New Order
column31: believing the Empire's promise of stability and security
column32: while others served reluctantly
column33: viewing their positions as opportunities to moderate Imperial excesses from within.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column34: the Exodeenian population found itself divided in loyalty. While Exodeen officially remained under Imperial control
column35: many citizens grew increasingly disillusioned with the Empire's oppression and brutality. The destruction of Alderaan particularly shocked Exodeenian society
column36: as it represented the ultimate betrayal of the values many Exodeenians had served throughout their careers.\n\nNumerous Exodeenians defected to the Rebel Alliance
column37: bringing with them valuable knowledge of Imperial bureaucracy and military organization. These defectors provided crucial intelligence and expertise to the Rebellion
column38: using their understanding of Imperial systems to help the Alliance strike effectively at the Empire. Exodeenian rebels served in various capacities
column39: from intelligence analysis to military command to diplomatic missions.\n\nThe division in Exodeenian society reflected the broader galactic struggle
column40: with families sometimes torn apart by conflicting loyalties. Some Exodeenians remained in Imperial service out of genuine belief in the Empire's mission
column41: while others stayed because they felt duty-bound to their positions or feared the consequences of defection. Meanwhile
column42: their relatives and former colleagues fought against the Empire with equal conviction.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column43: Exodeen joined the new government. The planet's population
column44: relieved by the Empire's defeat
column45: worked to rebuild democratic institutions and restore the values that had defined Exodeenian culture during the Republic era. Many Exodeenians who had served the Empire sought redemption by dedicating themselves to the New Republic's success.\n\nExodeenian expertise in administration and governance proved valuable to the New Republic as it struggled to establish effective government across liberated territories. The planet's tradition of public service continued
column46: with a new generation of Exodeenians leaving their homeworld to help build a better galaxy. The lessons learned during the dark years of Imperial rule reinforced Exodeenian commitment to democratic principles and the importance of remaining vigilant against tyranny."

Text: "Fedalle is a planet in the Core Worlds. An early member of the Galactic Republic
column4: it maintained loyalty to the galactic government for much of its history."

Text: "Fedalle is a terrestrial planet located in the Core Worlds region of the galaxy
column4: positioned along the Hydian Way hyperlane. A world of varied terrain including plains
column5: forests
column6: and urban centers
column7: Fedalle developed into a significant commercial and industrial hub due to its strategic location on one of the galaxy's most important trade routes.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column8: Fedalle joined the Galactic Republic and became an important waypoint for trade moving along the Hydian Way. The planet maintained steady economic growth throughout the millennia
column9: with its shipyards and manufacturing facilities producing vessels and equipment for both civilian and military use.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column10: Fedalle was known for its reliable industrial output and its position as a major trade hub connecting different regions of the Core Worlds. The planet's economy benefited from the constant flow of merchant traffic along the Hydian Way
column11: establishing Fedalle as a prosperous and strategically valuable world.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column12: Fedalle remained firmly loyal to the Galactic Republic. The planet's shipyards contributed vessels to the Republic Navy
column13: while its factories produced military equipment and supplies for the Grand Army of the Republic. Fedalle's strategic location made it an important logistics hub for Republic forces operating throughout the Core Worlds.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column14: Fedalle came under Imperial control. The Empire recognized the planet's industrial capacity and strategic position
column15: maintaining a significant garrison to protect vital shipyards and manufacturing facilities. Imperial oversight brought increased regulation to the planet's industrial sector
column16: with production quotas enforced to ensure continued supply of military hardware.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column17: Fedalle remained under Imperial control for most of the conflict. The planet's proximity to Coruscant and its industrial importance made it a priority for Imperial defense. However
column18: as the war progressed and Imperial authority began to fracture following the Battle of Endor
column19: Fedalle's status became increasingly contested.\n\nApproximately seven years after the Battle of Endor
column20: Fedalle became the site of a significant engagement between New Republic and Imperial forces. The planet had remained under Imperial control despite the Empire's defeats elsewhere
column21: with Imperial commanders recognizing its strategic value for maintaining a presence in the Core Worlds.\n\nThe New Republic launched a campaign to liberate Fedalle
column22: seeking to secure the planet's shipyards and deny them to Imperial remnant forces. The battle saw intense fighting both in space and on the planet's surface
column23: with New Republic forces ultimately succeeding in capturing the world. The liberation of Fedalle dealt another blow to Imperial authority in the Core Worlds and provided the New Republic with valuable industrial facilities.\n\nFollowing its liberation
column24: Fedalle joined the New Republic. The planet's shipyards and manufacturing facilities were converted to produce vessels and equipment for the New Republic Defense Fleet. Fedalle's strategic position along the Hydian Way ensured it remained an important world in the post-Imperial era
column25: contributing to the New Republic's efforts to rebuild galactic civilization and maintain security throughout the Core Worlds."

Text: "Felucia is a world in the Outer Rim. It is a lush jungle world
column4: populated with many strange plants
column5: animals
column6: and other organisms
column7: and steeped in powerful Force energies. Colonised by the Gossam species thousands of years before the formation of the Galactic Republic (But still home to other native sapient species)
column8: it was controlled by the Commerce Guild for much of its history
column9: and joined the Republic only decades before the outbreak of the Clone Wars. During the Clone Wars it joined the Confederacy of Independent Systems
column10: and many fierce battles were fought for control over the system. In the age of the Empire
column11: a garrison was maintained on the planet."

Text: "Felucia is a remote jungle planet located in the Outer Rim Territories
column4: positioned along the Perlemian Trade Route. One of the most verdant and lush worlds in the galaxy
column5: Felucia's surface is covered by dense fungal forests
column6: bioluminescent plants
