column7: and exotic flora that create a landscape unlike any other in known space.\n\nThe planet's ecosystem is dominated by massive fungi that tower hundreds of meters into the air
column8: creating a multi-layered canopy filled with strange and often dangerous creatures. The flora and fauna of Felucia have evolved in remarkable ways
column9: with many organisms displaying brilliant colors and bioluminescent properties. The entire planet is saturated with the Force
column10: creating a living environment where the boundary between plant and animal life often blurs.\n\nFelucia is home to several sentient species
column11: including the Felucians
column12: a primitive amphibian species who live in tribal communities within the jungle. The Felucians developed a shamanic culture centered around their connection to the Force and the planet's natural rhythms. They are sensitive to the Force and capable of using it to influence the growth of Felucia's plants and to bond with the planet's creatures.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column13: Felucia was colonized by the Gossam species
column14: who recognized the planet's potential for agricultural production despite its challenging environment. The Commerce Guild
column15: controlled by the Gossam
column16: established operations on Felucia to harvest the planet's unique plant life for pharmaceutical and agricultural exports. However
column17: the native Felucians continued to inhabit the deep jungles
column18: maintaining their traditional way of life.\n\nFor much of its history
column19: Felucia remained under Commerce Guild control
column20: with the Gossam maintaining plantations and processing facilities in cleared areas while the Felucians lived in the untamed wilderness. The planet joined the Galactic Republic only decades before the Clone Wars
column21: remaining a frontier world with limited Republic oversight.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column22: Felucia became contested when the Commerce Guild joined the Confederacy of Independent Systems. The planet's strategic position along the Perlemian Trade Route and its agricultural resources made it valuable to both sides. Republic forces launched several campaigns to secure Felucia
column23: leading to some of the most brutal jungle warfare of the entire conflict.\n\nThe Battle of Felucia saw Republic clone troopers fighting through dense vegetation against Separatist battle droids and organic forces. The planet's hostile environment proved as dangerous as enemy fire
column24: with poisonous plants
column25: aggressive predators
column26: and treacherous terrain claiming casualties on both sides. Jedi Generals including Aayla Secura led Republic forces in multiple engagements across Felucia's surface.\n\nNear the end of the Clone Wars
column27: Jedi Master Aayla Secura was stationed on Felucia with her clone trooper battalion. When Order 66 was executed
column28: Commander Bly and his troops turned on their Jedi General
column29: killing her in the jungle. Secura's death on Felucia was one of countless tragedies that marked the end of the Jedi Order.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column30: Felucia came under Imperial control. The Empire maintained a garrison on the planet to protect Commerce Guild operations and ensure continued production of agricultural exports. However
column31: the dense jungles and hostile wildlife made complete Imperial control difficult to enforce.\n\nDuring the early years of Imperial rule
column32: a group of former Jedi and Force-sensitives sought refuge on Felucia
column33: hoping the planet's strong Force presence would help conceal them from the Empire. These survivors attempted to live in harmony with the native Felucians
column34: though their presence eventually drew Imperial attention.\n\nImperial forces conducted periodic sweeps through Felucia's jungles
column35: hunting for hidden Jedi and suppressing any resistance from the native population. The Felucians
column36: protective of their jungle home
column37: occasionally came into conflict with Imperial forces
column38: using their knowledge of the terrain and ability to command local creatures to resist occupation.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column39: Felucia remained under Imperial control for most of the conflict. The planet's isolation and challenging environment meant it saw limited Rebel Alliance activity
column40: though the dense jungles occasionally provided refuge for Alliance operatives operating in the region.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column41: Felucia's fell under Corporate Sector Authority influence as they worked to expand their claims in the Outer Rim. The native Felucians continued their existence in the deep jungles
column42: largely unaffected by the changing galactic governments
column43: maintaining their ancient connection to the Force and the living world of Felucia."

Text: "Firrerre is a world in the Outer Rim. Once home to the Firrerro people
column4: it is now a barren world
column5: all of its life having been eradicated by the Empire with a lethal virus."

Text: "Firrerre is a terrestrial planet located in the Abrion sector of the Outer Rim Territories. The homeworld of the Firrerreo species
column4: a near-human race known for their distinctive two-toned hair
column5: golden skin
column6: and exceptional longevity
column7: Firrerre was once a world of considerable beauty and cultural richness.\n\nThe Firrerreo evolved as a long-lived species
column8: with lifespans extending for centuries. Their culture emphasized artistic expression
column9: philosophy
column10: and the careful cultivation of knowledge across generations. Firrerreo society placed great value on memory and oral tradition
column11: with their people serving as living repositories of their civilization's history.\n\nOne distinctive aspect of Firrerreo biology was their unusual relationship with their names. A Firrerreo who heard their full name spoken aloud would become weakened and vulnerable. This biological quirk shaped their culture profoundly
column12: with true names kept as closely guarded secrets. Most Firrerreo used pseudonyms or partial names in daily life.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column13: Firrerre maintained membership in the Galactic Republic
column14: though remained relatively isolated due to its remote location. The Firrerreo's long lifespans meant their civilization developed slowly
column15: with cultural changes occurring over centuries rather than decades. However
column16: this allowed Firrerreo scholars and artists to dedicate lifetimes to perfecting their crafts
column17: producing works of exceptional quality.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column18: Firrerre remained under Republic control
column19: its remote location sparing it from major battles.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column20: Firrerre's fate took a dark turn. The Empire targeted the Firrerreo species for extermination
column21: deploying a biological weapon against the planet. The Candorian plague
column22: a genetically-engineered virus designed to target Firrerreo biology
column23: swept across the planet with devastating efficiency
column24: killing most of the population within months.\n\nThe plague spread rapidly through Firrerreo communities. Infected individuals developed severe symptoms quickly
column25: with death following within days. Medical facilities were overwhelmed
column26: and quarantine measures proved ineffective. As the death toll mounted
column27: Firrerre's cities became mass graves. The Firrerreo's rich culture
column28: accumulated over thousands of years
column29: was extinguished in a biological holocaust.\n\nA handful of Firrerreo survived
column30: primarily those offworld when the virus was released. These survivors found themselves scattered across the galaxy
column31: the last remnants of a once-thriving civilization. Many went into hiding
column32: fearful the Empire might hunt down survivors.\n\nFollowing the plague
column33: Firrerre was left a dead world. The Empire established a quarantine zone
column34: preventing investigation and concealing evidence of their crime. The planet's cities stood as silent monuments to genocide
column35: slowly decaying without maintenance.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column36: Firrerre remained under Imperial quarantine. The Empire maintained patrol vessels to enforce the exclusion zone. Rumors of the genocide spread through Rebel Alliance intelligence networks
column37: though concrete evidence remained elusive.\n\nThe few surviving Firrerreo struggled to maintain their cultural identity while living in exile. Cut off from their homeworld and lacking critical mass to sustain traditions
column38: many aspects of Firrerreo culture began to fade. Some survivors worked to document what they remembered
column39: desperate to preserve something of their civilization.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor
column40: the truth about Firrerre began to emerge as Imperial files were uncovered. The New Republic investigated and officially recognized the genocide as one of the Empire's most heinous crimes.\n\nHowever
column41: investigation of Firrerre itself remained dangerous due to potential contamination. The New Republic maintained the quarantine while scientists studied whether the pathogen remained active. The planet stood as a grim memorial to Imperial cruelty.\n\nThe surviving Firrerreo
column42: numbering perhaps only in the hundreds across the galaxy
column43: worked to rebuild some semblance of community while mourning their loss. Their long lifespans meant many survivors would carry the memory of Firrerre's destruction for centuries
column44: living witnesses to genocide who would ensure their people's fate would not be forgotten."

Text: "Foless is a planet in the Colonies region
column4: at the edge of the Inner Rim. It lies at the meeting point of the Corellian Trade Spine hyperroute and the Shipwright's Trace."

Text: "Foless is a planet in the Colonies region
column4: located at the edge of the Inner Rim. It lies at the meeting point of the Corellian Trade Spine hyperroute and the Shipwright's Trace.\n\nA world of vast oceans and scattered island continents
column5: Foless was settled by human colonists during the early expansion era of the Old Republic. The planet became known for its shipbuilding facilities
column6: taking advantage of its strategic location along major trade routes.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column7: Foless remained loyal to the Republic and served as a minor naval staging point.\n\nUnder the Galactic Empire
column8: the planet's shipyards were pressed into service constructing Imperial vessels
column9: though on a smaller scale than major yards like Kuat or Corellia.\n\nThe native Foless were incorporated into galactic society
column10: though they maintained their traditional seafaring culture alongside modern starship construction. The planet's economy relied heavily on maritime industries and its position as a waypoint for traders moving between the Core and the Colonies."

Text: "Fondor is a planet in the Colonies region. A heavily industrialised ecumenopolis
column4: Fondor is one of the most prominent starship manufacturers in the galaxy
column5: outclassed only by Corellia and Kuat. During the Clone Wars
column6: it was ostensibly a member of the Confederacy of Independent Systems
column7: but most of its population was unsupportive of the Separatist cause
column8: and contributed little to the war effort. During the age of the Galactic Empire
column9: Fondor's shipyards were used for classified research and development."

Text: "Fondor is a heavily industrialized planet located in the Tapani sector of the Colonies region
column4: positioned along the Rimma Trade Route hyperlane. One of the galaxy's most important shipbuilding centers
column5: Fondor rivals Corellia and Kuat as a premier manufacturer of starships
column6: with its massive orbital shipyards producing vessels for various governments throughout galactic history.\n\nThe planet's surface is almost entirely covered by urban sprawl
column7: factories
column8: and industrial infrastructure devoted to starship construction and related industries. Fondor Shipyards
column9: the planet's primary manufacturing concern
column10: operates massive orbital construction facilities capable of building capital ships of all sizes. The shipyards have produced some of the most iconic vessels in galactic history
column11: establishing Fondor's reputation for quality engineering and innovative designs.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column12: Fondor joined the Galactic Republic and quickly became one of its most important industrial centers. The planet's strategic location along the Rimma Trade Route ensured steady economic growth
column13: with Fondor's shipyards producing both civilian and military vessels for Republic use throughout the millennia.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column14: Fondor maintained its position as a leading shipbuilding world
column15: competing with Corellia and Kuat for lucrative contracts. The planet's economy became intrinsically tied to starship construction
column16: with most of the population employed in the shipyards or supporting industries. Fondor's industrial capacity proved crucial during various galactic conflicts
column17: providing the Republic with much-needed warships.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column18: Fondor's allegiance became complicated. The planet officially joined the Confederacy of Independent Systems
column19: though this alignment was driven more by economic interests and political pressure than genuine support for the Separatist cause. Much of Fondor's population remained sympathetic to the Republic
column20: creating internal divisions that limited the planet's contribution to the Separatist war effort.\n\nDespite official Separatist control
column21: production at Fondor's shipyards remained relatively limited during the Clone Wars compared to other major industrial worlds. The workforce's reluctance to fully support the Confederacy
column22: combined with Republic efforts to disrupt operations
column23: meant that Fondor never became the Separatist powerhouse that Count Dooku had hoped for.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire and the end of the Clone Wars
column24: Fondor came under Imperial control. The Empire recognized the planet's strategic value and moved quickly to secure its shipyards and industrial infrastructure. Imperial authorities reorganized Fondor's manufacturing facilities
column25: pressing them into service producing vessels for the rapidly expanding Imperial Navy.\n\nUnder Imperial rule
column26: Fondor became one of the Empire's most important naval construction centers. The planet's shipyards produced Star Destroyers
column27: support vessels
column28:
and various other military craft throughout the Imperial era. The Empire maintained a strong military presence on Fondor to protect the valuable facilities and ensure continued productivity.

Fondor's shipyards were also used for classified research and development projects during the Imperial era. The Empire established secure facilities within the orbital yards where experimental technologies and prototype vessels could be developed away from prying eyes. These classified programs contributed to the development of various Imperial military innovations.

During the Galactic Civil War
column29: Fondor remained under firm Imperial control due to its strategic importance. The planet's shipyards continued producing vessels for the Imperial Navy throughout the conflict
column30: making Fondor a priority target for Rebel operations. However
column31: the strong Imperial garrison and orbital defenses deterred direct Rebel attacks on the facilities.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the Emperor's death
column32: Fondor's status became contested as various Imperial remnant factions and the New Republic competed for control of the valuable shipyards. The planet changed hands several times during the conflicts that followed
column33: with different factions recognizing that controlling Fondor meant controlling a significant portion of the galaxy's military shipbuilding capacity.\n\nApproximally 12 years after the Battle of Endor
column34: the New Republic finally secured control of Fondor
column35: though Imperial remnant forces continued to contest the planet's allegiance. The shipyards were converted to produce vessels for the New Republic Defense Fleet
column36: continuing Fondor's long tradition as one of the galaxy's premier centers of starship construction."

Text: "Fusai is a planet in the Outer Rim. It was home to a branch of the Celebratus Archive of Obroa-skai
column4: but once Obroa-skai abandoned the branch
column5: it was maintained locally. Fusai was a Rebel safe world during the age of the Empire
column6: and a supercomputer in the library aided the Rebels in tactical and strategic planning."

Text: "Fusai is a terrestrial planet located in the Outer Rim Territories. A world of varied terrain including forests
column4: plains
column5: and scattered urban centers
column6: Fusai developed as a modest center of learning and scholarship
column7: though it remained largely isolated from major galactic affairs for much of its history.\n\nThe planet's most notable feature is its library
column8: a branch facility of the renowned Celebratus Archive originally established by scholars from Obroa-skai. For thousands of years
column9: this repository of knowledge served researchers and students throughout the region
column10: maintaining extensive collections of texts
column11: data
column12: and historical records.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column13: Fusai maintained its connection to Obroa-skai's vast archive network
column14: receiving regular updates and contributions from the main facility. The planet attracted scholars seeking access to information that might not be available elsewhere in the Outer Rim
column15: establishing Fusai's reputation as a center of learning despite its remote location.\n\nHowever
column16: at some point in its history
column17: Obroa-skai abandoned the Fusai branch facility
column18: severing the connection between the two archives. The reasons for this decision remain unclear
column19: though it may have been related to the costs of maintaining such a distant outpost or shifts in Obroa-skai's priorities. Following the abandonment
column20: local scholars and administrators on Fusai took responsibility for maintaining the library
column21: preserving its collections and continuing its mission of knowledge preservation.\n\nThe library on Fusai contained a sophisticated supercomputer system
column22: a relic of its days as an official Celebratus Archive branch. This advanced computational infrastructure provided powerful data processing and analysis capabilities
column23: making the facility valuable not just as a repository of information but as a tool for complex research and strategic planning.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column24: Fusai remained nominally under Republic control
column25: though its remote location meant it saw little direct involvement in the conflict. The planet's scholars continued their work
column26: largely unaffected by the surrounding galactic turmoil.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column27: Fusai fell under nominal Imperial authority. However
column28: the Empire showed limited interest in the remote scholarly world
column29: maintaining only minimal oversight. This relative neglect allowed Fusai to maintain considerable autonomy in managing its affairs.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column30: Fusai's isolation and the Empire's lack of significant presence made it attractive to the Rebel Alliance. The planet became a safe world for Rebel operations
column31: providing a secure location away from Imperial scrutiny where Alliance personnel could operate with minimal risk of discovery.\n\nThe library's supercomputer proved invaluable to the Rebel cause. Alliance strategists and tacticians used the system's analytical capabilities to process intelligence
column32: model battle scenarios
column33: and develop strategic plans for operations throughout the Outer Rim. The combination of the library's extensive historical records and the supercomputer's processing power allowed Rebel commanders to study past conflicts and apply those lessons to their struggle against the Empire.\n\nRebel cells used Fusai as a meeting point and planning center
column34: taking advantage of the planet's scholarly reputation as cover for their activities. Alliance personnel could pose as researchers or students
column35: blending in with the legitimate academic community while conducting their resistance work.\n\nThe local population
column36: sympathetic to the Rebel cause
column37: provided additional security by maintaining the appearance of normalcy and alerting Alliance personnel to any unusual Imperial interest in the planet. This cooperative relationship between the Rebels and Fusai's inhabitants allowed the Alliance to maintain operations there throughout much of the Galactic Civil War.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column38: Fusai's status as a safe world for the Alliance became less critical as Imperial authority collapsed with no faction immediately claiming the planet.\n\nThe scholarly community on Fusai worked to rebuild connections with other academic institutions across the galaxy
column39: including potentially reestablishing ties with Obroa-skai. The planet maintained its character as a center of learning in the Outer Rim
column40: its library preserving knowledge accumulated over millennia while the supercomputer continued to serve researchers seeking to unlock the secrets of the past and plan for the future."

Text: "The Garos system is a six-planet star system in the Mid Rim. It is located near the Nyarikan Nebula."
"Garos IV is a temperate planet located in the Mid Rim
column4: near the Nyarikan Nebula. Its surface features lush forests
column5: rolling plains
column6: and rugged mountain ranges
column7: supporting a climate suitable for agriculture and habitation.\n\nThe planet is home to the native Garosians
column8: a human population that developed a peaceful agrarian society with a strong appreciation for the arts and democratic governance. Garos IV maintained close ties to the Galactic Republic for thousands of years
column9: though its remote location kept it largely isolated from major galactic events.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column10: Garos IV remained loyal to the Republic
column11: but its distance from major battlefronts spared it from direct conflict. The planet continued its traditional way of life
column12: focusing on agriculture and local culture.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column13: Garos IV came under Imperial control. The Empire established a garrison on the planet and imposed strict regulations
column14: seeking to suppress dissent and maintain order. Imperial rule led to growing resentment among the Garosian population
column15: with many citizens secretly opposing the Empire and supporting the Rebel Alliance.\n\nThe planet became a center for covert resistance activities
column16: with Garosians providing intelligence and resources to the Rebellion while maintaining the appearance of compliance with Imperial authority. The Imperial presence remained strong throughout the Galactic Civil War
column17: but local resistance persisted.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor
column18: Garos IV's status remained contested as Mandalorian clans
column19: Imperial remants
column20: and corporate forces vied for influence in the region."

Text: "The Gerrenthum system is located in the Anoat sector in the Outer Rim of the galaxy. It includes the planet Gerrenthum."
"Gerrenthum is a remote ice planet located in the Anoat sector of the Outer Rim Territories
column4: positioned along the Corellian Trade Spine hyperlane near the Greater Javin region. A frozen
column5: inhospitable world perpetually covered in thick layers of ice and snow
column6: Gerrenthum's surface features temperatures far below freezing across most of the planet
column7: with violent blizzards and treacherous ice formations dominating the landscape.\n\nThe planet remained largely unexplored and unsettled for much of galactic history due to its extreme environment and remote location. The harsh conditions made long-term habitation extraordinarily difficult
column8: with only the most determined colonists or desperate fugitives willing to endure Gerrenthum's frozen wastes.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column9: Gerrenthum was occasionally noted on star charts as a waypoint along the Corellian Trade Spine
column10: though few vessels made the journey to its frozen surface. The planet's lack of strategic resources and punishing environment meant it attracted minimal attention from governments or corporations.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column11: Gerrenthum's isolation kept it far from the conflict between the Republic and the Separatists. The planet remained effectively uninhabited
column12: its ice fields undisturbed by the galactic struggle.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column13: Gerrenthum fell under nominal Imperial authority as part of the Anoat sector. However
column14: the Empire showed little interest in the frozen world
column15: maintaining no permanent presence on its surface. The planet's location along the Corellian Trade Spine gave it some minor strategic relevance as a potential emergency stopover point
column16: though most spacers preferred to avoid it entirely.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column17: Gerrenthum's extreme isolation made it an occasional refuge for smugglers
column18: pirates
column19: and others seeking to avoid Imperial detection. The planet's harsh environment provided natural concealment
column20: with sensor readings often disrupted by ice storms and atmospheric interference. However
column21: few chose to remain on Gerrenthum for extended periods
column22: as survival on the frozen surface required constant struggle against the elements.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor
column23: Gerrenthum remained part of the Greater Javin region
column24: which fell under the Iron Blockade established by Imperial forces unwilling to accept reports of the Emperor's death. During this period of isolation
column25: the planet continued its existence as a frozen
column26: largely forgotten world on the edge of known space.\n\nFollowing the collapse of the Iron Blockade
column27: Gerrenthum's status remained uncertain as various Imperial remnant factions
column28: pirate clans
column29: and the New Republic competed for control of the Anoat sector. The planet's combination of strategic position along the Corellian Trade Spine and its utterly inhospitable environment ensured it remained a world of minimal settlement but occasional tactical significance."

Text: "Geonosis
column4: is a ringed
column5: rocky planet in the Arkanis sector of the Outer Rim Territories. The home planet of the insectoid Geonosians
column6: it is known for its droid factories and violent gladiatorial games. The desert world was the Confederacy of Independent Systems' first capital
column7: hosting its major droid foundries. It was the site of the Battle of Geonosis
column8: the opening conflict of the Clone Wars
column9: in 22 BBY."

Text: "Geonosis is a ringed
column4: rocky planet located in the Arkanis sector of the Outer Rim Territories
column5: positioned along the Corellian Trade Spine. The planet is characterized by its harsh desert climate
column6: massive rock formations
column7: and extensive underground hive complexes. Geonosis is the homeworld of the insectoid Geonosian species
column8: who live in a caste-based society led by hive queens and aristocrats
column9: with workers and warriors forming the bulk of the population.\n\nGeonosis remained largely isolated for much of galactic history due to its inhospitable environment and remote location. The Geonosians developed advanced technology
column10: specializing in droid manufacturing and engineering. Their underground foundries produced battle droids and starships for various clients
column11: making Geonosis a major industrial center in the Outer Rim.\n\nThe planet's society revolved around hive structures
column12: with gladiatorial combat serving as both entertainment and a means of enforcing social order. The Petranaki Arena in the capital was infamous for its brutal contests
column13: where prisoners and criminals faced deadly beasts for the amusement of Geonosian spectators.\n\nShortly before the Clone Wars
column14: Geonosis became a focal point of galactic events. Count Dooku and the Separatist movement established secret alliances with the planet's leadership
column15: including Archduke Poggle the Lesser. The Geonosians provided the Separatists with battle droids and weapons
column16: and the first Death Star plans were secretly developed on Geonosis.\n\nIn 22 BBY
column17: Jedi Knight Obi-Wan Kenobi discovered the Separatist presence on Geonosis while investigating an assassination attempt. Kenobi was captured and
column18: along with Anakin Skywalker and Padmé Amidala
column19: sentenced to death in the Petranaki Arena. Their execution was interrupted by a Jedi strike team led by Mace Windu
column20: sparking the Battle of Geonosis
column21: the opening conflict of the Clone Wars.\n\nRepublic clone troopers
column22: led by Jedi Generals
column23: fought Separatist droid armies across the planet's surface and in its orbital space. The battle resulted in heavy casualties on both sides
column24: with Count Dooku escaping and the Republic claiming victory. The Republic established a garrison on Geonosis to prevent further Separatist activity
column25: but the Geonosians continued to resist through guerrilla tactics and underground operations.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column26: Geonosis remained a major battleground. The planet's droid foundries were repeatedly targeted by Republic forces
column27: including a second major assault led by Jedi Generals Obi-Wan Kenobi
column28: Anakin Skywalker
column29: and Ki-Adi-Mundi. During this campaign
column30: Jedi Master Luminara Unduli and Padawan Barriss Offee destroyed key droid factories
column31: and the Republic uncovered evidence of advanced weapons development.\n\nGeonosis was also the site of the creation of the Death Star's superweapon plans
column32: which were handed to Count Dooku by Poggle the Lesser. The plans were later delivered to Darth Sidious
column33: setting the stage for the Empire's ultimate weapon.\n\nAfter the Clone Wars
column34: Geonosis fell under Imperial control. The Empire used the planet's foundries for secret construction projects
column35: including the initial assembly of the Death Star. To conceal these activities
column36: the Empire sterilized Geonosis
column37: releasing biological weapons that wiped out nearly the entire Geonosian population. Only a handful of survivors remained
column38: including a lone queen who attempted to preserve her species.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column39: the Rebel Alliance discovered evidence of the genocide and the Death Star's origins on Geonosis. The planet remained a barren wasteland
column40: its hive cities abandoned and its foundries silent.\n\In the years following the Battle of Endor
column41: Geonosis's native population was still small
column42: with only a few Geonosians surviving in hidden underground chambers. Corporations like Hoersch-Kessel Drive
column43: Inc. took advantage of the power vacuum to convert the planet's facilities for their own use. The planet's legacy as the birthplace of the Death Star and the site of the Clone Wars' first battle remained a grim reminder of the consequences of galactic conflict."

Text: "Giju is a planet located in the galaxy's Colonies region along the Rimma Trade Route."
"Giju is a terrestrial planet located in the Colonies region of the galaxy
column4: positioned along the Giju Run hyperlane. A world of varied terrain including plains
column5: forests
column6: and urban centers
column7: Giju developed into a modest commercial hub due to its strategic location along regional trade routes.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column8: Giju was discovered during the early expansion era of the Galactic Republic. The planet joined the Republic and maintained steady economic growth over millennia
column9: serving as a waypoint for traders and travelers moving through the Colonies.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column10: Giju remained a relatively quiet world
column11: its economy based primarily on trade services
column12: light manufacturing
column13: and agriculture. The planet never achieved the prominence of major commercial centers
column14: but its position along the Giju Run ensured continued prosperity through merchant traffic.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column15: Giju remained loyal to the Galactic Republic. The planet's strategic location made it valuable for Republic logistics
column16: serving as a minor supply depot and rest stop for military convoys moving through the Colonies region.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column17: Giju came under Imperial authority. The Empire established a presence on the planet to maintain order and monitor trade along the Giju Run
column18: though the garrison remained relatively modest given the world's limited strategic importance.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column19: Giju remained under Imperial control for most of the conflict. The planet's location made it useful for Imperial supply lines
column20: though it avoided becoming a major battleground due to its distance from primary conflict zones.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column21: Giju's status became contested as various Imperial remnant factions and the New Republic competed for control of strategic positions in the Colonies region."

Text: "Gizer is a planet famed for the manufacturing of the Gizer L-6 freighter and gizer ale."
"Gizer is a terrestrial planet located in the Outer Rim Territories. A minor
column4: unremarkable world with limited industrial development
column5: Gizer maintained a quiet existence throughout most of galactic history
column6: remaining largely peripheral to major political and economic affairs.\n\nThe planet's surface features varied terrain suitable for habitation
column7: though it never developed into a significant population center.\n\nGizer's economy remained modest throughout the millennia
column8: based primarily on local agriculture and small-scale manufacturing. The planet became known for producing Gizer ale
column9: a locally brewed beverage that gained some popularity in nearby systems.\n\nThe planet also gained minor recognition as the homeworld of Gizer L-6 freighters
column10: a modest line of cargo vessels produced by local shipyards. While these freighters were reliable and serviceable
column11: they never achieved the renown of vessels from major manufacturers like Corellian Engineering Corporation or Kuat Drive Yards.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column12: Gizer remained under Republic control
column13: though its remote location meant it saw little direct involvement in the conflict. The planet continued its quiet existence despite the surrounding galactic turmoil.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column14: Gizer came under Imperial authority. The Empire maintained only minimal oversight of the planet
column15: focusing its attention on more strategically important worlds. Local authorities retained considerable autonomy in managing day-to-day affairs.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column16: Gizer remained under nominal Imperial control
column17: serving primarily as a minor waypoint for vessels traveling through the Outer Rim. The planet's lack of military or economic significance meant it avoided becoming a battleground in the larger conflict.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column18: Gizer's gained independence purely because no faction saw it as a priority."

Text: "Glee Anselm is a peaceful water planet in the Mid Rim. The planet's surface is largely covered in water or swamps
column4: with only a few clear landmasses dotting its surface. The planet have very frequent season changes
column5: causing it to be ravaged by intense storms with some of them turning cyclonic. The climate is moderate most of the standard year round."

Text: "Glee Anselm is an oceanic planet located in the Jalor system of the Mid Rim's Bortele sector
column4: positioned along the Llanic Spice Route hyperlane. The planet's surface is almost entirely covered by water
column5: with only three small continents and a modest archipelago breaking the endless waves. The vast oceans dominate the landscape
column6: creating a world where aquatic life thrives in countless forms.\n\nGlee Anselm is home to two native sentient species. The Nautolans
column7: amphibious humanoids with distinctive head-tails and large black eyes
column8: are equally comfortable in water and on land. Their society developed a culture that emphasized family bonds and communal cooperation
column9: with the oceans serving as the center of their civilization. The Anselmi
column10: a reptilian species
column11: inhabit the coastal regions and islands
column12: having evolved as primarily terrestrial beings who maintain an uneasy relationship with their amphibious neighbors.\n\nThe planet experiences dramatic seasonal changes throughout its long orbital period
column13: bringing powerful storms and cyclones that sweep across the oceans and landmasses. These seasonal shifts shaped both species' cultures
column14: with Nautolan communities building underwater cities that could withstand the storms
column15: while the Anselmi constructed their settlements in sheltered coastal areas.\n\nTensions between the Nautolans and Anselmi have existed for millennia
column16: with territorial disputes and cultural differences occasionally erupting into conflict. However
column17: both species eventually joined the Galactic Republic thousands of years before the rise of the Empire
column18: learning to coexist under Republic oversight.\n\nOne of the most famous Nautolans in galactic history was Kit Fisto
column19: a Jedi Master who served on the Jedi High Council during the final years of the Republic. Master Fisto was renowned for his combat prowess
column20: his infectious smile
column21: and his exceptional skill at underwater fighting. His presence on the Council demonstrated the respect Nautolans commanded throughout the galaxy.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column22: Glee Anselm remained firmly loyal to the Galactic Republic. The planet contributed to the war effort
column23: with Nautolan warriors serving in the Grand Army of the Republic and Kit Fisto leading Republic forces in numerous battles. The planet's strategic position along the Llanic Spice Route made it valuable for Republic military logistics.\n\nKit Fisto served with distinction throughout the Clone Wars
column24: participating in major battles including the Battle of Geonosis and leading aquatic assault operations where his natural abilities gave Republic forces a significant advantage. However
column25: when Order 66 was executed near the war's end
column26: Master Fisto was killed alongside Jedi Masters Mace Windu
column27: Saesee Tiin
column28: and Agen Kolar while attempting to arrest Chancellor Palpatine in his office on Coruscant.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column29: Glee Anselm came under Imperial authority. The Empire established a garrison on the planet to maintain order and ensure compliance with Imperial regulations. The loss of Kit Fisto and the Jedi Purge deeply affected Nautolan society
column30: though open resistance to the Empire remained limited due to the substantial Imperial military presence.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column31: Glee Anselm remained under Imperial control for most of the conflict. However
column32: many Nautolans privately sympathized with the Rebel Alliance
column33: viewing the fight against the Empire as continuing the Republic ideals that Jedi like Kit Fisto had died defending. Some Nautolans joined the Rebellion
column34: serving as pilots
column35: soldiers
column36: and support personnel.\n\nThe tensions between Nautolans and Anselmi persisted throughout the Imperial era
column37: though both species faced common challenges under Imperial occupation. The Empire showed little interest in mediating their disputes
column38: focusing primarily on extracting resources and maintaining security along the Llanic Spice Route.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column39: Glee Anselm's status became contested as various Imperial remnant factions and the New Republic competed for control of strategic positions along the Llanic Spice Route."

Text: "Gyndine is a planet in the Expansion Region. It is a local administrative center
column4: and have mid-sized
column5: advanced shipyards."

Text: "Gyndine is a planet in the Expansion Region
column4: located along the Hydian Way hyperlane. A heavily industrialized world known for its advanced shipyards
column5: Gyndine served as a regional administrative center and major production facility for centuries.\n\nThe planet's surface is dominated by sprawling urban centers and industrial complexes
column6: with Gyndine's shipyards producing a variety of vessels ranging from civilian transports to military warships. The world's strategic position along one of the galaxy's busiest trade routes ensured its economic prosperity and military importance.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column7: Gyndine remained loyal to the Galactic Republic
column8: with its shipyards contributing significantly to the Republic's naval efforts. The planet's factories produced components and complete vessels for the Grand Army of the Republic throughout the conflict.\n\nUnder the Galactic Empire
column9: Gyndine's importance only increased
column10: as the Imperial Navy made extensive use of the planet's shipbuilding capabilities. The Empire maintained a strong military presence on Gyndine to protect its valuable industrial infrastructure and ensure continued production of Imperial vessels.\n\nThe planet's population
column11: predominantly human with significant alien minorities
column12: worked primarily in manufacturing and shipbuilding industries. Despite heavy industrialization
column13: Gyndine maintained several preserved natural areas and historical districts in its older city centers."

Text: "Hapes is the homeworld of the Hapans
column4: a near-Human race known for their beauty
column5: and the administrative capital of the Hapes Consortium."

Text: "Hapes is a temperate planet located in the Hapes Cluster of the Inner Rim Territories
column4: positioned within the Lorelli Reach region. The capital world of the Hapes Consortium and homeworld of the Hapan species
column5: Hapes has served as the seat of power for the matriarchal government ruled by the Queen Mother for thousands of years.\n\nThe planet's surface features varied terrain including forests
column6: mountains
column7: and coastal regions
column8: with the capital city of Ta'a Chume'Dan serving as the administrative and cultural heart of the Consortium. Hapan architecture is renowned throughout the galaxy for its elegant design
column9: with soaring towers and graceful structures that reflect the species' aesthetic sensibilities.\n\nThe Hapan species are near-humans known for their exceptional physical beauty
column10: a trait carefully cultivated over millennia of selective breeding within the isolated Hapes Cluster. Hapan society is strictly matriarchal
column11: with women holding all positions of political power and most property rights. This social structure developed from the Consortium's unique history.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column12: the Hapes Cluster was controlled by pirates known as the Lorell Raiders
column13: who preyed on passing ships throughout the region. These raiders would capture beautiful women from the vessels they attacked
column14: bringing them back to the cluster. When the Jedi Order finally defeated the Lorell Raiders
column15: the captured women and their descendants took control
column16: establishing the matriarchal society that would define Hapan culture.\n\nThe Transitory Mists
column17: a dense nebula surrounding the Hapes Cluster
column18: provided natural protection and enforced isolation from the rest of the galaxy. This barrier made navigation into and out of the cluster extremely difficult
column19: with only a few safe routes known to Hapan pilots. The isolation allowed the Hapes Consortium to develop independently
column20: creating a unique culture and advanced technology separate from the galactic mainstream.\n\nHapan Battle Dragons and Nova-class battle cruisers became some of the most formidable warships in the known galaxy
column21: featuring innovative designs and powerful weapons systems. The Consortium maintained a substantial military force
column22: the Hapan Royal Navy
column23: primarily for defensive purposes given their isolationist policies.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column24: the Hapes Consortium maintained minimal contact with the Galactic Republic
column25: preferring to focus on internal affairs within the cluster. The matriarchal government
column26: led by successive Queen Mothers
column27: established a complex political system involving the Royal Court and representatives from the Consortium's sixty-three inhabited worlds.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column28: the Hapes Consortium maintained strict neutrality
column29: refusing to commit forces to either the Republic or the Confederacy of Independent Systems. The Transitory Mists continued to serve as an effective barrier
column30: keeping the conflict at a distance from Hapan territory.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column31: the Hapes Consortium continued its isolationist policies. The Empire showed little interest in penetrating the Transitory Mists to conquer the cluster
column32: and the Consortium had no desire to become entangled in Imperial politics. Queen Mother Ta'a Chume ruled during much of this period
column33: maintaining the Consortium's independence through careful diplomacy and the implicit threat of the powerful Hapan Royal Navy.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column34: the Hapes Consortium remained officially neutral
column35: though some limited trade occurred with both Imperial and independent systems. The Consortium's weapons and technology occasionally found their way to black markets
column36: though the government maintained tight control over exports of military hardware.\n\nQueen Mother Ta'a Chume gave birth to a son
column37: Isolder
column38: who became Prince of Hapes and heir to the throne. As the sole male heir in the matriarchal society
column39: Isolder's future marriage became a matter of significant political importance
column40: with various noble houses within the Consortium vying to have their daughters chosen as his bride.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column41: the Hapes Consortium began cautiously opening diplomatic relations with the outside galaxy. Prince Isolder
column42: seeking to end the Consortium's isolation
column43: proposed marriage to Princess Leia Organa as a means of forging an alliance between the Consortium and the New Republic. Though Leia ultimately married Han Solo instead
column44: the diplomatic overture marked the beginning of the Consortium's emergence from millennia of isolation."

Text: "Hosnian Prime is a planet in the Hosnian system of the Core Worlds
column4: located along the Corellian Trade Spine."

Text: "Hosnian Prime is a temperate planet in the Hosnian system of the Core Worlds
column4: located along the Corellian Trade Spine hyperlane. A world of vast oceans dotted with numerous island chains and archipelagos
column5: Hosnian Prime developed into a major commercial and political center due to its strategic location on one of the galaxy's most important trade routes.\n\nThe planet's surface features sprawling cities built across its island landmasses
column6: connected by advanced infrastructure including orbital space stations and atmospheric traffic lanes. Its capital city serves as a hub for interstellar commerce and diplomacy.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column7: Hosnian Prime was an influential member world
column8: contributing significantly to galactic trade and governance. The planet maintained its importance through the Clone Wars
column9: remaining loyal to the Republic despite the surrounding conflicts.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column10: Hosnian Prime continued to serve as an important commercial world
column11: though it fell under Imperial oversight like much of the Core. The planet's strategic value ensured a continued Imperial presence throughout the Galactic Civil War.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the Empire's decline
column12: Hosnian Prime became a prominent member of the New Republic. The planet's combination of economic prosperity and political stability made it an attractive location for the New Republic's rotating capital system."

Text: "Hoth is the sixth planet of the remote Hoth system. A desolate world covered with ice and snow
column4: located in the Anoat sector
column5: a rarely-travelled portion of the Outer Rim Territories
column6: it became famous as the one-time location of the Alliance to Restore the Republic's Echo Base during the Galactic Civil War."

Text: "Hoth is a remote ice planet located in the Anoat sector of the Outer Rim Territories. The sixth planet in the Hoth system
column4: it orbits a blue-white star and features a harsh
column5: frozen environment with extreme cold temperatures
column6: violent blizzards
column7: and a landscape dominated by ice plains
column8: glaciers
column9: and snow-covered mountain ranges.\n\nThe planet remained largely unexplored for much of galactic history due to its remote location and inhospitable conditions. Hoth's surface is perpetually covered in snow and ice
column10: with temperatures well below freezing even during the daytime. The planet's ecosystem
column11: though limited
column12: includes several native species adapted to the extreme cold
column13: most notably the massive wampa ice creatures that hunt across the frozen wastes and the tauntaun
column14: herbivorous reptomammals used by the Rebel Alliance as mounts.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column15: Hoth gained galactic significance when the Rebel Alliance established Echo Base within the planet's frozen caverns following their evacuation from Yavin 4. The Alliance chose Hoth specifically because its remote location and harsh environment made it an unlikely target for Imperial searches. Echo Base was constructed within a system of ice caves on the planet's northern hemisphere
column16: with the Rebels installing a powerful shield generator to protect against orbital bombardment.\n\nFor a time
column17: the secret base served as the Alliance's primary headquarters
column18: housing military command
column19: starfighter squadrons
column20: and support personnel. However
column21: Imperial probe droids eventually discovered the base's location
column22: leading to one of the most significant battles of the Galactic Civil War.\n\nThe Battle of Hoth saw the Empire deploy overwhelming force against Echo Base
column23: including a ground assault led by AT-AT walkers that breached the defensive perimeter. Despite determined resistance from Alliance forces
column24: including the successful use of snowspeeders to destroy several AT-ATs
column25: the Rebels were forced to evacuate the planet. While the Alliance suffered significant losses in equipment and supplies
column26: the evacuation protocols allowed most personnel to escape
column27: with transports fleeing the system as soon as the shield generator was disabled.\n\nFollowing the battle
column28: Hoth returned to its former obscurity. The ruins of Echo Base remained in the ice
column29: a frozen monument to one of the Rebellion's most desperate hours. The planet occasionally attracted scavengers seeking salvage from the battlefield
column30: though the hostile environment and remaining dangers made such expeditions risky.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column31: Hoth remained an uninhabited world
column32: its harsh climate preventing colonization. The planet serves as a reminder of the Alliance's struggle against the Empire and their ability to endure even in the most hostile environments."

Text: "Huk is the home planet of the Yam'rii species
column4: also known as the Huk (a Kaleesh slur translating as ""soulless bug""). The planet is mostly covered with dense forests."

Text: "Huk is a terrestrial planet located in the Bootana Hutta region of the Outer Rim Territories. The homeworld of the insectoid Yam'rii species
column4: Huk is covered by dense forests and features a humid climate well-suited to its native inhabitants.\n\nThe Yam'rii
column5: also known as the Huk
column6: a Kaleesh slur meaning ""soulless bug""
column7: developed a technologically advanced and expansionist civilization. Thousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column8: the Yam'rii began colonizing nearby worlds
column9: including the planet Kalee
column10: home of the reptilian Kaleesh species.\n\nThe Yam'rii's aggressive expansion led to the outbreak of the Huk War
column11: a brutal conflict between the Yam'rii and the Kaleesh. The Yam'rii sought to enslave the Kaleesh and exploit Kalee's resources
column12: while the Kaleesh
column13: led by the legendary warrior Qymaen jai Sheelal
column14: fought fiercely to defend their homeworld. The war saw the Kaleesh drive the Yam'rii from Kalee and launch retaliatory raids against Huk and other Yam'rii colonies.\n\nThe Yam'rii appealed to the Galactic Republic for intervention
column15: portraying themselves as victims of Kaleesh aggression. The Republic
column16: swayed by Yam'rii diplomacy
column17: intervened on behalf of the Yam'rii and imposed harsh sanctions on Kalee
column18: crippling the Kaleesh economy and leaving lasting resentment.\n\nThe aftermath of the Huk War had far-reaching consequences. Qymaen jai Sheelal
column19: embittered by the Republic's actions
column20: would later become the cyborg General Grievous
column21: a key figure in the Clone Wars. The Yam'rii continued to inhabit Huk
column22: maintaining their advanced society and recovering from the devastation of the conflict.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column23: Huk remained aligned with the Republic
column24: and the planet's strategic location in the Outer Rim ensured continued relevance in galactic affairs.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column25: Huk fell under Imperial control along with much of the region
column26: though the Yam'rii retained their distinct cultural identity and technological prowess."

Text: "Hypori is a planet located in the Hypori system of the Ferra sector in the Outer Rim Territories. It is home to no sentient species
column4: though it is host to windrails and massiffs. Its surface is covered in rocky landscapes and small oceans."

Text: "Hypori is a barren
column4: rocky planet located in the Hypori system of the Ferra sector in the Outer Rim Territories. A desolate world characterized by harsh terrain
column5: jagged rock formations
column6: and limited vegetation
column7: Hypori remained largely uninhabited by sentient species throughout most of galactic history.\n\nThe planet's surface features vast expanses of rocky badlands
column8: scattered with boulders and broken terrain that makes navigation difficult. Small oceans dot the landscape
column9: though these bodies of water support only limited ecosystems. The native fauna includes massiffs
column10: large quadrupedal predators
column11: and windrails
column12: avian creatures adapted to the planet's harsh environment.\n\nFor thousands of years
column13: Hypori attracted little attention from the broader galactic community due to its inhospitable conditions and lack of valuable resources. The planet remained largely unexplored
column14: with only occasional survey missions documenting its barren surface.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column15: Hypori's isolation ended when the Confederacy of Independent Systems established a significant military presence on the planet. The Separatists recognized that Hypori's remote location and harsh terrain made it an ideal location for secret military operations and droid manufacturing facilities.\n\nThe Techno Union
column16: one of the Confederacy's most important member organizations
column17: constructed extensive droid factories on Hypori's surface. These facilities produced battle droids for the Separatist war effort
column18: taking advantage of the planet's isolation to operate away from Republic surveillance. The harsh environment proved no obstacle to droid manufacturing
column19: as the automated workers required no life support or comfortable conditions.\n\nApproximately two years into the Clone Wars
column20: the Battle of Hypori became one of the conflict's most significant engagements. A Republic task force
column21: including several Jedi Generals
column22: was ambushed by Separatist forces led by General Grievous. The cyborg commander personally engaged the Jedi in combat
column23: demonstrating the devastating martial prowess that would make him one of the Republic's most feared enemies.\n\nDuring the battle
column24: Grievous killed several Jedi
column25: including Ki-Adi-Mundi's former Padawan
column26: Shaak Ti
column27: and seriously wounded others. The surviving Jedi
column28: including Ki-Adi-Mundi
column29: Aayla Secura
column30: and Shaak Ti
column31: were forced to take shelter in a damaged assault ship while clone troopers attempted to hold off the advancing droid army. The arrival of Republic reinforcements led by ARC trooper Captain Fordo eventually allowed the survivors to escape
column32: though the Battle of Hypori demonstrated the Republic's vulnerability and Grievous's deadly capabilities.\n\nFollowing this engagement
column33: Hypori remained under Separatist control for much of the Clone Wars. The Techno Union continued to operate its droid factories on the planet
column34: producing battle droids and other military equipment for the Confederacy. Republic forces launched several attempts to capture or destroy these facilities
column35: though the planet's hostile terrain and strong Separatist defenses made such operations extremely costly.\n\nNear the end of the Clone Wars
column36: Republic forces finally succeeded in capturing Hypori
column37: dealing a significant blow to the Separatist war effort. The planet's droid factories were shut down or destroyed
column38: eliminating an important source of Separatist military production.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire and the end of the Clone Wars
column39: Hypori came under Imperial control. The Empire maintained a minimal presence on the planet
column40: primarily to ensure the former Separatist facilities remained decommissioned. The harsh environment and lack of economic value meant that Imperial oversight remained limited
column41: with the planet returning to its former obscurity.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column42: Hypori remained under nominal Imperial control
column43: though the planet saw little military activity. Its remote location and barren surface made it strategically insignificant compared to other worlds in the Outer Rim.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column44: Hypori's long quiet Separatist facilities sprung to life has the new homeworld of the Independent Commerce Guild."

Text: "Ilum is an ice planet in the Unknown Regions
column4: one of the main sources of the valuable Adegan crystals used in the construction of Jedi lightsabers. The caverns containing the crystals were long ago turned into a Jedi temple. Unlike the crystals of other planets
column5: the crystals of Ilum are limited to blue
column6: green and purple in colour. The planet is over ninety percent-covered by ice."

Text: "Ilum is a remote ice planet located deep within the Unknown Regions of the galaxy. The world's surface is almost entirely covered by glaciers and ice fields
column4: with perpetual snowstorms sweeping across the frozen landscape. Despite its harsh environment
column5: Ilum holds tremendous significance to the Jedi Order as one of the primary sources of kyber crystals used in lightsaber construction.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column6: the Jedi discovered Ilum and recognized the unique properties of its kyber crystals. These naturally occurring crystals
column7: found deep within ice caverns beneath the planet's surface
column8: resonated with the Force in ways that made them ideal for focusing a lightsaber's blade. The Jedi established a sacred temple on Ilum
column9: building it into the planet's icy mountains to serve as both a place of meditation and a waypoint for Padawans undertaking the ancient ritual of constructing their first lightsabers.\n\nThe Crystal Caves of Ilum became one of the Jedi Order's most sacred sites. Young Jedi were brought to Ilum as part of their training
column10: where they would venture into the caves in a ritual known as ""The Gathering."" Each Padawan would meditate and allow the Force to guide them to the kyber crystal that called to them. This deeply personal connection between Jedi and crystal was considered a crucial step in a Padawan's journey toward becoming a Jedi Knight.\n\nThe kyber crystals of Ilum naturally produced blue
column11: green
column12: yellow
column13: and occasionally purple lightsaber blades. Each crystal's unique properties would harmonize with its wielder
column14: creating a bond that lasted throughout the Jedi's life. The Jedi Temple on Ilum maintained this tradition for millennia
column15: with generations of Jedi making the pilgrimage to the frozen world.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column16: Ilum remained a closely guarded secret of the Jedi Order. The temple continued to serve its sacred purpose
column17: with Padawans still traveling there to find their crystals despite the surrounding galactic conflict. The planet's location in the Unknown Regions and the Jedi's careful protection kept it hidden from the Separatists.\n\nFollowing the execution of Order 66 and the rise of the Galactic Empire
column18: Ilum's fate changed dramatically. The Empire discovered the planet's location and recognized the strategic value of its kyber crystals. While the Jedi had used these crystals for lightsabers
column19: the Empire saw them as vital components for their superweapon projects
column20: particularly the Death Star's superlaser.\n\nImperial forces invaded Ilum
column21: desecrating the ancient Jedi Temple and converting the planet into a massive mining operation. The Empire stripped away vast portions of the planet's icy surface
column22: extracting kyber crystals on an industrial scale. Massive excavation equipment carved deep into Ilum's core
column23: transforming the sacred world into a source of raw materials for Imperial weapons.\n\nThe Empire's exploitation of Ilum continued throughout the Galactic Civil War. The planet's kyber crystals were shipped to various Imperial facilities
column24: including the construction sites of both Death Stars. The once-pristine ice world became scarred by mining operations
column25: its natural beauty destroyed in service of Imperial military ambitions.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the Emperor's death
column26: Imperial remnant forces maintained control of Ilum
column27: recognizing its continued strategic value. The mining operations continued
column28: though on a reduced scale as the fractured Empire struggled to maintain its grip on remote territories in the Unknown Regions."

Text: "Imynusoph is an Outer Rim Territories astronomical object located in grid square J-21 of the Standard Galactic Grid. It is situated at the endpoint of the super-hyperroute known as the Hydian Way
column4: which connect it to the celestial body Terminus."

Text: "Imynusoph is a remote
column4: terrestrial planet located in the Outer Rim Territories at the endpoint of the Hydian Way super-hyperroute
column5: connecting it to Terminus. A world of vast oceans dotted with scattered island chains
column6: Imynusoph remained largely isolated from galactic affairs throughout much of its history.\n\nThe planet's surface features a single major landmass alongside numerous smaller archipelagos
column7: with most settlements concentrated along coastal regions. The native Imynusophi species developed a maritime culture
column8: becoming skilled seafarers and traders despite their world's distance from major population centers.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column9: Imynusoph served primarily as a waypoint for vessels traveling the furthest reaches of the Hydian Way. Its strategic position at the terminus of this major trade route gave it some economic importance
column10: though the planet never developed into a major commercial hub.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column11: Imynusoph maintained neutrality
column12: with its remote location sparing it from major conflicts. The planet's isolation proved both a blessing and a curse
column13: as it avoided the devastation of war but also struggled to maintain contact with the galactic community.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column14: Imynusoph fell under nominal Imperial control
column15: though the Empire maintained only a minimal presence due to the planet's peripheral location and limited strategic value. Local governance largely remained in the hands of planetary authorities
column16: with Imperial oversight limited to ensuring compliance with basic Imperial regulations.\n\nThe planet's economy relied primarily on fishing
column17: aquaculture
column18: and limited trade with passing vessels. Imynusoph never developed significant industrial infrastructure
column19: maintaining its character as a quiet
column20: isolated world on the edge of known space."

Text: "Isde Naha is a world in the Outer Rim
column4: located at the edge of the Greater Javin region. It is a highly industrialised world that strongly disapproves of smuggling."

Text: "Isde Naha is a terrestrial planet located in the Outer Rim Territories
column4: positioned at the edge of the Greater Javin region along the Corellian Trade Spine. A heavily industrialized world with a strong manufacturing base
column5: Isde Naha developed into a significant economic center despite its remote location.\n\nThe planet's surface is dominated by sprawling factory complexes and urban centers devoted to industrial production. Its economy relies heavily on manufacturing and trade
column6: with goods flowing along the Corellian Trade Spine to markets throughout the Outer Rim and beyond.\n\nIsde Naha maintains a strict stance against smuggling and illicit trade
column7: with planetary authorities enforcing rigorous customs inspections and trade regulations. This reputation for law and order has made the planet a preferred destination for legitimate commerce
column8: though it has also made it unpopular with smugglers and independent traders who prefer less scrutinized routes.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column9: Isde Naha fell under Imperial control. The Empire maintained a garrison on the planet to protect its industrial facilities and ensure the continued flow of manufactured goods to Imperial markets.\n\nFollowing the Battle of Endor and the fragmentation of Imperial authority
column10: the planet's status remained uncertain as various Imperial remnant factions
column11: pirate clans
column12: and the New Republic vied for control of strategic Outer Rim worlds."

Text: "Ithor is a planet in the Mid Rim. Home to the Ithorian people
column4: it is a lush and vibrant world
column5: teeming with life. This life was carefully guarded and tended to by the Ithorians
column6: living in massive floating cities
column7: and few people ever set foot on the surface."

Text: "Ithor is a lush terrestrial planet located in the Ottega system of the Mid Rim Territories
column4: positioned along the Lesser Lantillian Route hyperlane. Often called the ""Mother Jungle"" by its inhabitants
column5: Ithor is one of the most verdant and ecologically diverse worlds in the known galaxy
column6: with its surface covered entirely by dense tropical rainforests
column7: sprawling jungles
column8: and vast plains of vegetation.\n\nThe planet is home to the Ithorian species
column9: peaceful herbivorous beings known for their distinctive hammer-shaped heads
column10: long curved necks
column11: and two mouths positioned on opposite sides of their necks. The Ithorians
column12: sometimes called ""Hammerheads"" by other species
column13: developed one of the galaxy's most environmentally conscious civilizations
column14: building their entire society around the principle of preserving and nurturing their planet's ecosystem.\n\nRather than constructing cities on Ithor's surface
column15: the Ithorians built massive floating herdships - kilometer-long repulsorlift vessels that drift through the atmosphere above the jungle canopy. These elegant spacecraft serve as mobile cities
column16: agricultural centers
column17: and trade vessels
column18: allowing Ithorian civilization to thrive without disturbing the pristine wilderness below. Each herdship is a self-contained ecosystem
column19: featuring gardens
column20: farms
column21: and spaces for thousands of Ithorians to live and work.\n\nIthorian culture holds the surface of their homeworld as sacred ground. The ""Law of Life"" strictly governs interaction with the planet below
column22: with each Ithorian permitted to visit the surface only three times in their lifetime - once as a youth
column23: once as an adult
column24: and once as an elder. This tradition ensures the jungle remains largely untouched by sapient interference
column25: preserving its natural state for future generations.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column26: Ithor joined the Galactic Republic and became renowned throughout the galaxy for the Ithorians' ecological expertise and peaceful nature. Ithorian herdships traveled widely
column27: trading agricultural products and ecological services while sharing their philosophy of environmental stewardship with other worlds.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column28: the Ithorians earned respect as some of the galaxy's premier ecologists and agricultural scientists. Their herdships became mobile universities where other species could learn sustainable farming techniques and environmental management. The Ithorians' patient
column29: methodical approach to problem-solving made them valued mediators and advisors throughout the Mid Rim.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column30: Ithor remained loyal to the Galactic Republic. The planet's strategic location and the Ithorians' reputation for honesty made it an important neutral meeting ground for diplomatic negotiations. Ithorian herdships continued their travels throughout the conflict
column31: providing food and medical supplies to Republic forces and civilian populations affected by the war.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column32: Ithor came under Imperial oversight. The Empire established a presence on several Ithorian herdships to monitor trade and collect taxes
column33: though the Ithorians' peaceful nature and lack of military significance meant Imperial interference remained limited. The Ithorians continued their traditional way of life
column34: maintaining their environmental laws despite occasional Imperial pressure to exploit Ithor's resources.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column35: Ithor officially remained under Imperial control
column36: though many Ithorians privately sympathized with the Rebel Alliance. The species' commitment to peace and life made them natural opponents of the Empire's destructive policies. Some Ithorian herdships covertly supported the Rebellion
column37: providing supplies and safe harbor for Alliance operatives while maintaining the appearance of Imperial loyalty.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column38: Ithor found itself on the frontline
column39: desired by multiple factions.\n\nThe planet's pristine jungles remained protected by the Law of Life
column40: standing as a testament to what the galaxy could achieve through careful stewardship and respect for the natural world. Ithor continued to serve as a symbol of hope that life
column41: given proper care and protection
column42: could flourish even in a galaxy marked by conflict and destruction."

Text: "Jabiim is a terrestrial world in the Outer Rim
column4: located along the Triellus Trade Route. A planet of constant torrential rains
column5: Jabiim's environment has been heavily polluted by decades of strip mining
column6: and its heavily ionised atmosphere now produces dangerous electrical storms and acid rain. The world has been a constant target for warfare
column7: bandit and pirate raids
column8: and plagues. During the Clone Wars
column9: Jabiim joined the Confederacy of Independent Systems due to feelings of being abandoned by the Republic
column10: and many costly campaigns by the Grand Army were waged to bring it back under Republic control
column11: shortly before the end of the war. During the age of the Empire
column12: the planet was strip mined
column13: leading to resistance movements striking Imperial holdings."

Text: "Jabiim is a rain-soaked terrestrial planet located in the Outer Rim Territories along the Triellus Trade Route. The world is infamous for its perpetual storms
column4: muddy terrain
column5: and frequent lightning
column6: with rainfall occurring almost constantly across its surface. Jabiim's landscape is dominated by rolling hills
column7: bogs
column8: and marshes
column9: making travel and settlement difficult for its inhabitants.\n\nThe native Jabiimi are a human population known for their resilience and resourcefulness
column10: having adapted to the planet's harsh climate and challenging environment. Jabiim's economy has historically relied on mining
column11: with rich deposits of minerals beneath its muddy surface. However
column12: decades of strip mining have left much of the planet scarred and polluted
column13: contributing to environmental degradation and hazardous weather conditions.\n\nDuring the final years of the Galactic Republic
column14: Jabiim became a major battleground in the Clone Wars. The planet's leadership
column15: feeling neglected by the Republic
column16: sided with the Confederacy of Independent Systems. The Battle of Jabiim was one of the bloodiest campaigns of the war
column17: with Republic clone troopers and Jedi fighting in brutal conditions against determined Separatist forces and local resistance. The conflict resulted in heavy casualties on both sides
column18: and the Republic was ultimately forced to withdraw
column19: leaving the planet under Separatist control.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column20: Jabiim fell under Imperial occupation. The Empire continued to exploit the planet's mineral resources
column21: intensifying strip mining operations and further damaging the environment. Imperial rule was harsh
column22: with local resistance movements forming in response to oppression and resource exploitation. The planet's population endured years of hardship under Imperial control
column23: with many Jabiimi joining or supporting rebel activities against the Empire.\n\nDuring the Imperial era
column24: Jabiim became a waypoint for refugees and fugitives seeking passage out of Imperial territory. The planet's remote location and constant storms made it a useful hiding place for those evading Imperial authorities. Secret routes and safe houses were established by underground networks to help people escape
column25: including Force-sensitives hunted by the Empire.\n\nJabiim's legacy as a world of constant rain
column26: mud
column27: and conflict has made it a symbol of endurance and struggle in the galaxy. Its history is marked by the resilience of its people and the lasting scars of war and exploitation."

Text: "Jakku is a planet in the Western Reaches of the Inner Rim. Once a lush and forested world
column4: a past calamity has rendered it a scorched
column5: barren desert. Few sapients inhabit this largely ignored planet
column6: save for those that do not wish to hide."

Text: "Jakku is a remote desert planet located in the Western Reaches of the Inner Rim Territories
column4: positioned along the Rimma Trade Route. A harsh
column5: unforgiving world covered almost entirely by vast expanses of sand dunes
column6: rocky outcroppings
column7: and the scorching heat of its sun
column8: Jakku is one of the most inhospitable inhabited planets in known space.\n\nThe planet's surface is dominated by endless desert wastes
column9: with scattered settlements of scavengers and moisture farmers eking out meager existences among the dunes. Jakku's ecosystem is remarkably barren
column10: with only the hardiest creatures surviving in the extreme conditions. The native steelpeckers
column11: heat-adapted insects
column12: and various desert predators represent the sparse wildlife that has evolved to endure the planet's harsh environment.\n\nFor thousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column13: Jakku remained largely unknown and unexplored. Its remote location and lack of valuable resources meant few spacers ventured to the isolated world. However
column14: archaeological evidence suggests Jakku once held significance in the ancient past
column15: with mysterious ruins and artifacts scattered beneath its sands hinting at a civilization long forgotten.\n\nThousands of years before the Empire
column16: Jakku was discovered to harbor fragments of dark side knowledge and ancient Sith artifacts buried in its deserts. The exact nature of these relics and the civilization that left them remains a mystery
column17: though some scholars theorize the planet may have served as a repository or place of exile in ages past.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column18: Jakku remained an insignificant backwater world
column19: rarely appearing on standard navigation charts. The few settlers who established themselves on the planet were typically fugitives
column20: religious hermits
column21: or desperate colonists seeking isolation from galactic civilization. These hardy individuals built small communities around what few moisture sources existed
column22: surviving through scavenging and subsistence farming.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column23: Jakku's isolation kept it far from the conflict between the Republic and the Separatists. The planet continued its existence in obscurity
column24: with its inhabitants largely unaware of and unaffected by the galactic struggle.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column25: Emperor Palpatine took a personal interest in Jakku.
