The Emperor discovered the planet harbored ancient dark side energies and established secret research facilities in the deep desert to study these phenomena. Imperial archaeologists and dark side adepts conducted excavations seeking ancient Sith knowledge
column26: though much of this activity remained highly classified.\n\nPalpatine also established Jakku as part of his Contingency plan - a series of protocols designed to ensure that if he died
column27: the Empire would not survive him. The planet was chosen as one of several locations where these contingency operations would be centered
column28: though the full extent of the Emperor's plans for Jakku remained known only to his most trusted servants.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column29: Jakku remained under nominal Imperial control
column30: though the Empire maintained only a minimal garrison given the planet's lack of strategic importance. The secret Imperial facilities continued their work in isolation
column31: hidden from both the wider Empire and the Rebel Alliance.\n\nApproximately one year after the Battle of Endor and the Emperor's death
column32: Jakku became the site of one of the most significant battles in galactic history. Imperial forces
column33: following protocols from the Emperor's Contingency
column34: gathered at Jakku for a final confrontation with the New Republic. The Battle of Jakku saw massive fleets clash in orbit while ground forces fought across the desert surface.\n\nThe battle raged for days
column35: with both sides suffering heavy casualties. Dozens of Star Destroyers
column36: including Super Star Destroyers
column37: were destroyed in orbit
column38: their flaming wreckage crashing into Jakku's desert surface. The carnage was immense
column39: with thousands of vessels and millions of personnel engaged in desperate combat.\n\nThe New Republic emerged victorious
column40: though at great cost. The battle marked the decisive end of the Galactic Civil War
column41: with the Empire's defeat at Jakku forcing the surviving Imperial leadership to sue for peace. The Galactic Concordance
column42: signed shortly after
column43: officially ended the conflict and severely restricted the remnants of the Empire.\n\nFollowing the battle
column44: Jakku's desert became a massive graveyard of destroyed Imperial and New Republic vessels. The wrecks of Star Destroyers jutted from the sands like tombstones
column45: creating the largest starship debris field in the known galaxy.\n\nIn the years after the battle
column46: Jakku's population grew as scavengers arrived from across the galaxy
column47: seeking to salvage valuable technology and components from the wrecked vessels. These scavengers established settlements like Niima Outpost
column48: where salvaged goods could be traded for food
column50: and supplies. The economy became entirely based on scavenging
column51: with traders purchasing salvage and selling it to various interests throughout the galaxy.\n\nThe New Republic maintained a presence on Jakku immediately following the battle
column52: working to secure dangerous materials and prevent the spread of Imperial weapons technology. However
column53: as years passed and the New Republic focused on rebuilding galactic civilization
column54: oversight of Jakku diminished. The planet returned to its status as a remote desert world
column55: though now dotted with the ruins of one of history's greatest battles."

Text: "The Greater Javin is a backwater region of space in the Western Reaches of the Outer Rim. It is comprised of three subsectors: Javin
column4: Anoat
column5: and Yarith. It was explored five hundred years before the rise of the Galactic Empire by entrepreneur Ecclessus Figg
column6: whose scouts expanded the Corellian Trade Spine into and beyond the Greater Javin region."

Text: "The Greater Javin is a remote region of space located in the Outer Rim Territories
column4: positioned within the Western Reaches and encompassing three subsectors: the Javin subsector
column5: the Anoat subsector
column6: and the Yarith subsector. This isolated area has maintained a distinct identity throughout galactic history
column7:
characterized by its distance from major population centers and its unique economic and cultural development.

The Greater Javin region remained largely unexplored and unsettled for much of galactic history due to its remote location and the navigational challenges posed by the surrounding space. The region's isolation kept it off most major trade routes and navigation charts during the Old Republic era.

Approximately five hundred years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column8: the renowned entrepreneur and explorer Ecclessis Figg launched expeditions into the region. Figg's scouts charted new hyperspace routes extending the Corellian Trade Spine into and through the Greater Javin
column9: opening the area to colonization and commercial exploitation. This exploration proved crucial to the region's subsequent development.\n\nFigg himself became one of the Greater Javin's most important figures
column10: establishing Cloud City on Bespin and founding various other commercial ventures throughout the region. His efforts transformed the Greater Javin from an unexplored backwater into a viable
column11: if still remote
column12: area of settlement and economic activity.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column13: the Greater Javin developed slowly
column14: attracting independent settlers
column15: miners
column16: and entrepreneurs seeking opportunities away from the heavily regulated Core Worlds. The region's isolation allowed for a degree of independence and self-governance unusual even for the Outer Rim.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column17: the Greater Javin maintained a position of relative neutrality
column18: with most worlds in the region avoiding formal alignment with either the Republic or the Confederacy of Independent Systems. The area's remoteness spared it from major battles
column19: though its resources and strategic position attracted occasional interest from both sides.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column20: the Greater Javin came under nominal Imperial control. However
column21: the region's distance from Imperial Center meant that Imperial authority remained limited in practice. Local governments and criminal organizations
column22: particularly elements of the Hutt Cartel
column23: wielded considerable power throughout the region.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column24: the Greater Javin remained under Imperial oversight
column25: though many inhabitants privately sympathized with the Rebel Alliance. The region's industries
column26: particularly tibanna gas production on Bespin
column27: contributed to the Imperial economy.\n\nFollowing the Battle of Endor and the death of Emperor Palpatine
column28: Imperial forces in the Greater Javin refused to accept reports of the Empire's defeat. Moff Adelhard
column29: the regional Imperial governor
column30: established what became known as the Iron Blockade
column31: sealing off the entire Greater Javin region from the rest of the galaxy. This military cordon prevented news of the Emperor's death from reaching the sector's inhabitants and blocked all travel in or out of the region.\n\nThe Iron Blockade lasted for several months
column32: during which time the Greater Javin existed in isolation
column33: its population unaware of the dramatic changes occurring in the wider galaxy. Imperial forces within the blockade maintained order through increasingly authoritarian measures
column34: while resistance movements began to form among the trapped populations.\n\nEventually
column35: the Iron Blockade collapsed as Imperial authority fragmented and the truth about the Emperor's death could no longer be suppressed. The Greater Javin emerged from isolation to find the galaxy fundamentally changed
column36: with the New Republic rising to challenge the remnants of the Empire.\n\nFollowing the blockade's end
column37: the Greater Javin's status remained contested between various Imperial remnant factions
column38: pirate clans
column39: and the New Republic. The region's isolation and distinct character persisted even as it slowly integrated into the post-Imperial galactic order."

Text: "Jedha
column4: also known as the Pilgrim Moon
column5: or as the Cold Moon
column6: is a small desert moon which orbited the planet NaJedha. The historical and spiritual significance of Jedha led the moon to become a world of worship for those who believed in the Force
column7: and a holy site for pilgrims who sought spiritual guidance.\nJedha City was once located on the surface of this moon
column8: but it was destroyed by the Empire."

Text: "Jedha is a small desert moon located in the Mid Rim Territories
column4: orbiting the planet NaJedha in the Jedha system. A cold
column5: arid world with a thin atmosphere
column6: Jedha's surface is dominated by vast deserts
column7: rocky mesas
column8: and ancient ruins that have stood for millennia.\n\nFor thousands of years
column9: Jedha has been revered throughout the galaxy as one of the first civilizations to explore the nature of the Force. The moon became a spiritual center and place of pilgrimage for those who believed in the Force
column10: regardless of their specific traditions or interpretations. Jedha's significance transcended any single organization
column11: with the moon serving as holy ground for believers from countless cultures and eras.\n\nThe moon's surface is dotted with ancient temples
column12: monasteries
column13: and sacred sites built by various Force-worshipping cultures over millennia. The Temple of the Kyber
column14: also known as the Temple of the Whills
column15: stood as one of Jedha's most sacred locations. This massive structure
column16: carved from stone and built around natural kyber crystal formations
column17: served as a center of worship and study for the Guardians of the Whills and other Force devotees.\n\nJedha's greatest treasure was its vast deposits of kyber crystals
column18: naturally occurring gems that resonated with the Force. These crystals formed in massive caverns beneath the moon's surface
column19: creating a spiritual resonance that many believed made Jedha itself alive with the Force. For millennia
column20: Jedi traveled to Jedha to obtain kyber crystals for their lightsabers
column21: viewing the pilgrimage as an important spiritual journey.\n\nJedha City
column22: built among ancient ruins in a deep canyon
column23: served as the moon's primary settlement. The Holy City
column24: as it was known
column25: featured architecture spanning thousands of years
column26: with newer structures built atop and around ancient temples and monuments. The city's narrow streets and crowded markets bustled with pilgrims
column27: monks
column28: and traders from across the galaxy.\n\nThe Guardians of the Whills
column29: an ancient order devoted to protecting Jedha's spiritual sites and preserving knowledge of the Force
column30: maintained temples and monasteries throughout the moon. Though not Jedi
column31: the Guardians served as protectors of Jedha's holy places and guides for pilgrims seeking spiritual enlightenment.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column32: Jedha maintained its traditional neutrality
column33: welcoming pilgrims and Force-sensitives from all sides of the conflict. The moon's spiritual significance meant most factions respected its sacred status
column34: though the war disrupted pilgrim traffic and brought hardship to the local population.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire and the Jedi Purge
column35: Jedha's importance took on a darker dimension. The Empire recognized the moon's kyber crystal deposits as vital for their secret superweapon projects
column36: particularly the Death Star. Imperial forces occupied Jedha
column37: establishing a massive mining operation to extract kyber crystals on an industrial scale.\n\nThe occupation transformed Jedha into a police state. Stormtroopers patrolled the streets of the Holy City
column38: and Imperial cargo shuttles constantly transported extracted kyber crystals off-world. The Empire's mining operations desecrated sacred sites and ancient temples
column39: stripping away rock to reach crystal deposits beneath. Many of Jedha's spiritual traditions were suppressed
column40: with the Empire viewing Force worship as a dangerous remnant of the Jedi Order.\n\nThe Guardians of the Whills and other spiritual groups were persecuted under Imperial rule. Some went into hiding
column41: while others formed resistance cells to fight against the occupation. The once-peaceful moon became a center of insurgent activity
column42: with various rebel groups conducting guerrilla operations against Imperial forces.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column43: Jedha remained under Imperial occupation. The moon's strategic importance as a source of kyber crystals ensured continued Imperial presence despite persistent resistance. Saw Gerrera
column44: an extremist rebel leader
column45: established operations on Jedha
column46: conducting increasingly violent attacks against Imperial forces.\n\nShortly before the Battle of Yavin
column47: the Empire tested the Death Star's superlaser on Jedha. Director Orson Krennic ordered a low-power shot to demonstrate the station's capabilities and eliminate Saw Gerrera's rebels. The blast completely destroyed the Holy City and created a massive crater
column48: killing millions including Saw Gerrera and his followers. The destruction was officially attributed to a mining disaster by Imperial propaganda.\n\nThe attack left Jedha devastated but not destroyed. However
column49: the moon's orbit was destabilized by the blast
column50: and debris from the destroyed city created a deadly ring around the moon. The surviving population was forced to evacuate as the moon's environment became increasingly uninhabitable.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the Empire's defeat
column51: Jedha remained a scarred and largely abandoned world
column52: its once-thriving spiritual community scattered across the galaxy. The moon stood as a grim monument to Imperial brutality and the cost of the Death Star project that had consumed so many lives and resources."

Text: "Kabal is a planet in the Outer Rim. Before the Clone Wars
column4: Confederate interference led to massive food shortages on the world
column5: in a plot to encourage Kabal to secede from the Republic. The operation was successful
column6: and the planet joined the Separatists. During the Galactic Civil War
column7: Kabal maintained neutrality against both the Empire and the Rebel Alliance
column8: even in spite of an Imperial assault on the Conference of Uncommitted Worlds being held there."

Text: "Kabal is a terrestrial planet located in the Kabal system of the Outer Rim Territories. A world of varied terrain including plains
column4: forests
column5: and urban centers
column6: Kabal developed as a modest agricultural and manufacturing center
column7: maintaining membership in the Galactic Republic for thousands of years.\n\nDuring the final years of the Galactic Republic
column8: Kabal became a target of Separatist manipulation. The Confederacy of Independent Systems orchestrated a covert operation to destabilize the planet's economy and create conditions that would encourage Kabal to secede from the Republic. Through sabotage and interference with supply chains
column9: the Separatists engineered massive food shortages across Kabal
column10: causing widespread suffering among the population.\n\nAs the crisis deepened
column11: many Kabalians blamed the Republic for failing to protect their interests or provide adequate relief. The Separatists capitalized on this discontent
column12: offering aid and promising that independence from the Republic would bring prosperity. The operation proved successful - Kabal officially seceded from the Republic and joined the Confederacy of Independent Systems shortly before the outbreak of the Clone Wars.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column13: Kabal remained under Separatist control
column14: contributing resources to the Confederacy's war effort. The planet's strategic location in the Outer Rim made it valuable for Separatist logistics
column15: serving as a waypoint for supply convoys moving through the region.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire and the end of the Clone Wars
column16: Kabal came under Imperial authority. The transition proved difficult for many Kabalians
column17: who had joined the Separatists seeking independence rather than embracing authoritarian rule. The Empire established a garrison on the planet to maintain order and ensure compliance with Imperial regulations.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column18: Kabal adopted a position of strict neutrality
column19: refusing to commit to either the Galactic Empire or the Rebel Alliance. The planet's leadership sought to avoid the mistakes that had led them into the Clone Wars
column20: maintaining independence from both sides of the conflict.\n\nKabal's neutral stance made it an attractive location for diplomatic gatherings between uncommitted worlds. At some point during the Galactic Civil War
column21: the planet hosted the Conference of Uncommitted Worlds
column22: a meeting of planetary representatives who had chosen to remain neutral in the conflict between the Empire and the Rebellion.\n\nThe conference drew Imperial attention
column23: and Imperial forces launched an assault on Kabal in an attempt to disrupt the gathering and intimidate the neutral worlds into supporting the Empire. The attack demonstrated the Empire's willingness to use military force against worlds that refused to openly declare loyalty
column24: even when those worlds maintained official neutrality.\n\nDespite the Imperial assault
column25: Kabal maintained its neutral position throughout the remainder of the Galactic Civil War. The planet's leadership refused to be coerced into choosing sides
column26: viewing both the Empire and the Rebellion as outside powers whose conflicts threatened Kabal's independence.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column27: Kabal's status remained uncertain. The planet's history of manipulation by outside powers during the Clone Wars and its experience with Imperial aggression during the Galactic Civil War left its population wary of making commitments to any galactic government. The Kabalians worked to maintain their independence while carefully navigating the complex political landscape of the post-Imperial era."

Text: "Kadavo is a planet in Wild Space. A barren world of dormant volcanoes and thick smog
column4: Kadavo was part of the Zygerrian Slave Empire
column5: and housed a slave processing facility. During the Clone Wars
column6: a colony of Togruta was kidnapped by the Zygerrians and transported here
column7: but a Republic force
column8: led by General Anakin Skywalker
column9: raided the facility and destroyed it
column10: freeing the slaves."

Text: "Kadavo is a volcanic planet located in the Kadavo system within the Outer Rim Territories. A harsh
column4: inhospitable world characterized by active volcanism
column5: toxic atmosphere
column6: and oppressive heat
column7: Kadavo's surface is dominated by lava flows
column8: ash fields
column9: and jagged volcanic peaks that pierce through perpetual clouds of sulfurous gas.\n\nFor thousands of years
column10: Kadavo served as a major hub of the Zygerrian Slave Empire
column11: an ancient civilization built on the exploitation of conquered peoples. The Zygerrians established massive slave processing facilities on Kadavo
column12: taking advantage of the planet's hostile environment as a natural deterrent to escape. The volcanic conditions and toxic atmosphere ensured that slaves transported to Kadavo had virtually no hope of fleeing into the wilderness.\n\nThe slave processing facility on Kadavo was an enormous complex suspended above active lava flows
column13: accessible only by air. This fortress-like installation served as a holding center where newly captured slaves were broken
column14: trained
column15: and prepared for sale throughout Zygerrian space. The facility's design was deliberately cruel
column16: with cages suspended over molten lava and minimal life support
column17: ensuring complete control over the captive population through fear and the constant threat of death.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column18: the Jedi Order helped the Galactic Republic destroy the Zygerrian Slave Empire
column19: liberating countless beings held in bondage across their territories. Following this defeat
column20: Kadavo's slave facilities were abandoned and the planet fell into obscurity
column21: though the Zygerrians never forgot their former glory.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column22: approximately 21 years before the rise of the Empire
column23: the Zygerrian Slave Empire attempted to rebuild its former power by allying with the Confederacy of Independent Systems. The Zygerrians
column24: led by Queen Miraj Scintel
column25: began conducting slaving operations throughout the Outer Rim
column26: capturing Republic citizens and selling them into servitude.\n\nThe Zygerrians reactivated the slave processing facility on Kadavo
column27: bringing it back into operation under the command of Keeper Agruss
column28: a sadistic Zygerrian administrator who took pleasure in tormenting the slaves under his control. The facility resumed its original function as a center for breaking and processing captives.\n\nWhen a colony of 50
column29: 000 Togruta from the neutral world of Kiros disappeared
column30: the Jedi Council dispatched Master Obi-Wan Kenobi
column31: Anakin Skywalker
column32: and Ahsoka Tano to investigate. The Jedi discovered that the Zygerrians had kidnapped the entire population and were transporting them to the slave markets.\n\nThe rescue attempt went awry when the Jedi were captured by Queen Scintel. While Skywalker was held captive on the Zygerrian homeworld
column33: Kenobi and Captain Rex were transported to Kadavo as slaves
column34: forced to witness the suffering of the Togruta colonists held in the facility's horrific conditions.\n\nKeeper Agruss used Kenobi's presence to demonstrate Zygerrian power
column35: torturing both the Jedi Master and the Togruta captives while boasting of the Zygerrians' return to prominence. The facility's defenses included numerous guards
column36: electrified cages
column37: and the constant threat of dropping prisoners into the lava below.\n\nSkywalker
column38: having escaped from Zygerria following Queen Scintel's death at the hands of Count Dooku
column39: led a Republic assault on Kadavo to rescue the captives. Republic forces
column40: including clone troopers and Jedi
column41: attacked the facility despite being outnumbered by Zygerrian guards and facing the installation's formidable defenses.\n\nDuring the battle
column42: Keeper Agruss attempted to execute the slaves by dropping their cages into the lava
column43: but was killed by the Togruta colonist Governor Roshti before he could complete his revenge. The Republic forces succeeded in overwhelming the Zygerrian guards and destroying the facility's critical systems.\n\nWith the installation disabled and the guards defeated
column44: Republic forces evacuated all 50
column45: 000 Togruta colonists along with other slaves held at the facility. The slaves were returned to their homeworlds
column46: and the Kadavo slave processing center was left in ruins.\n\nFollowing the Republic's victory at Kadavo
column47: the Zygerrian Slave Empire's resurgence was dealt a significant blow. The destruction of their primary processing facility and the loss of thousands of potential slaves severely damaged their operations and their credibility with their Separatist allies.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column48: Kadavo remained a largely abandoned world
column49: its ruined slave facility standing as a grim monument to Zygerrian cruelty and the Republic's eventual triumph. The planet's hostile environment ensured few chose to return to the volcanic wasteland.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column50: Kadavo continued its existence as a forgotten world in the Outer Rim
column51: its dark history remembered primarily by those who had suffered there and those who had fought to end its nightmare."

Text: "Kalee is a planet located in Wild Space. Home to the warlike Kaleesh
column4: it is a harsh
column5: tropical world
column6: covered in the Kaleeshi's temple-like homes. Since the planet's introduction to the galactic community
column7: Kalee has sent its people to serve as warriors
column8: bodyguards
column9: and mercenaries for many conflicts and parties. Decades before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column10: the Republic convinced the Kaleesh to wage war against an isolationist neighbour
column11: then sided against them in their conflict with the insectoid Huks. A prominent Kaleesh general during the Huk War
column12: Qymaen jai Sheelal
column13: eventually became the dreaded Separatist cyborg Grievous."

Text: "Kalee is a harsh tropical world located in the Mytaranor sector of the Expansion Region
column4: though its remote position places it effectively in Wild Space. The homeworld of the reptilian Kaleesh species
column5: Kalee features dense jungles
column6: arid badlands
column7: and numerous predatory creatures that shaped the evolution of its fierce warrior inhabitants.\n\nThe Kaleesh developed a culture centered on honor
column8: warfare
column9: and spiritual beliefs. Their society reveres fallen warriors
column10: with religious practices involving ancestor worship and the wearing of bone masks that grant spiritual protection. Kaleesh architecture features distinctive temple-like structures called Shrupak
column11: built to honor their gods and ancestors.\n\nFor much of galactic history
column12: Kalee remained isolated
column13: with the Kaleesh developing independently until discovered by Republic explorers. The planet's harsh environment and the Kaleesh's fierce nature meant colonization attempts were minimal
column14: with the species maintaining control over their homeworld.\n\nApproximately forty years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column15: Kalee faced invasion by the insectoid Yam'rii from the neighboring planet Huk. The Yam'rii
column16: also known as the Huk
column17: sought to colonize Kalee and enslave its population. The invasion sparked the devastating Huk War
column18: which would define a generation of Kaleesh.\n\nThe Kaleesh warrior Qymaen jai Sheelal emerged as the species' greatest hero during this conflict. Leading Kaleesh forces with brilliant tactical skill and ferocious determination
column19: he drove the Yam'rii from Kalee and pursued them back to their own worlds. The Kaleesh campaign became a war of vengeance
column20: with warriors following Sheelal in raids against Yam'rii colonies.\n\nHowever
column21: the Yam'rii appealed to the Galactic Republic for aid
column22: portraying the Kaleesh as aggressors. The Republic
column23: unaware of the full context of the conflict and swayed by Yam'rii diplomacy
column24:
intervened on behalf of the Huk. Republic forces blockaded Kalee and demanded the Kaleesh end their campaign.

The Republic's intervention devastated Kalee. Economic sanctions and the cost of the prolonged war left the planet impoverished. Many Kaleesh starved as resources dwindled. The species that had successfully defended their homeworld found themselves punished by the galactic government they had hoped would support them.

Qymaen jai Sheelal
column25: the hero who had saved his people
column26: was left bitter and disillusioned. The Republic's betrayal
column27: as he saw it
column28: fostered deep resentment toward galactic institutions. This bitterness would later be exploited by the InterGalactic Banking Clan
column29: which offered to rebuild Kalee's economy in exchange for Kaleesh service as enforcers.\n\nSheelal himself was critically injured in a shuttle crash. The Banking Clan
column30: seeing potential in the legendary warrior
column31: transformed him into a cyborg and gave him a new identity: General Grievous. The transformation stripped away much of his Kaleesh identity while preserving his tactical genius and combat prowess.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column32: many Kaleesh served as mercenaries and warriors for various factions. Their reputation for ferocity and skill made them highly sought after
column33: with Kaleesh warriors serving as elite troops and bodyguards throughout the galaxy. However
column34: General Grievous's prominence as Supreme Commander of the Separatist Droid Army brought mixed feelings to his homeworld.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column35: Kalee fell under nominal Imperial control
column36: though the Empire maintained only minimal presence on the remote world. The Kaleesh's warrior culture and isolation meant they continued their traditional way of life with little Imperial interference.\n\nMany Kaleesh left their homeworld to serve as mercenaries
column37: bounty hunters
column38: and warriors throughout the galaxy. Their distinctive bone masks
column39: reptilian features
column40: and fearsome combat abilities made them recognizable throughout the Outer Rim and beyond.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column41: Kalee remained officially neutral
column42: though individual Kaleesh served both the Empire and the Rebel Alliance as mercenaries. The planet's isolation from major conflict zones meant it avoided becoming a battleground in the larger struggle.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column43: Kalee's status remained uncertain. The planet's poverty and isolation meant no major faction prioritized establishing control
column44: leaving the Kaleesh to govern themselves while their warriors continued serving as mercenaries across the galaxy."

Text: "Kamino is an aquatic world beyond the Outer Rim. Located between the primary galaxy and one of its satellite dwarf galaxies
column4: the Rishi Maze
column5: Kamino is home to the enigmatic Kaminoans
column6: who had mastered genetic engineering and cloning technologies to save themselves from the ecological disaster that flooded their world. Known only to a few members of the Republic for thousands of years
column7: Kamino suddenly became a critical asset leading up to and during the Clone Wars
column8: in which the clone troopers of the Grand Army of the Republic were created on the planet. After the conflict
column9: the Galactic Empire forcibly relocated the Kaminoans and their technology
column10: and destroyed every facility on the planet."

Text: "Kamino is a remote aquatic planet located in Wild Space
column4: positioned south of the Rishi Maze satellite dwarf galaxy. The entire surface of Kamino is covered by a vast
column5: stormy ocean
column6: with no landmasses breaking the endless waves. The native Kaminoans constructed massive stilted cities rising above the turbulent seas
column7: creating elegant spires that pierce through the planet's perpetual storm clouds.\n\nThe Kaminoans are a tall
column8: graceful species known for their pale skin
column9: elongated necks
column10: and large
column11: almond-shaped eyes adapted to their world's dim light. They are renowned throughout the galaxy as master cloners and genetic engineers
column12: having developed these technologies over millennia to adapt their species to Kamino's changing environment.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column13: Kamino underwent dramatic climate change that caused the planet's ice caps to melt
column14: flooding the surface and forcing the Kaminoans to adapt or perish. Rather than abandon their homeworld
column15: they turned to genetic manipulation
column16: modifying their own species to survive in the new aquatic environment while simultaneously perfecting cloning technologies that would eventually make them famous throughout the galaxy.\n\nThe Kaminoans established Tipoca City as their capital
column17: a massive facility that served as both a population center and the heart of their cloning industry. The city's gleaming white structures became synonymous with Kaminoan technological achievement
column18: housing sophisticated laboratories and cloning facilities capable of producing organisms with unprecedented precision.\n\nFor much of galactic history
column19: Kamino remained isolated from the broader galactic community. The planet's location in Wild Space
column20: combined with the Kaminoans' preference for privacy regarding their work
column21: meant that few outsiders visited the world. However
column22: the Kaminoans maintained contacts with select clients throughout the galaxy
column23: offering their cloning services to those who could afford them and meet their exacting standards.\n\nApproximately ten years before the Clone Wars
column24: Jedi Master Sifo-Dyas
column25: acting without the knowledge or approval of the Jedi Council
column26: secretly commissioned the Kaminoans to create a clone army for the Galactic Republic. Using the bounty hunter Jango Fett as the genetic template
column27: the Kaminoans began producing millions of clone troopers
column28: trained from birth for military service.\n\nThe Sith Lord Darth Tyranus
column29: publicly known as Count Dooku
column30: became involved in the project after Sifo-Dyas's death
column31: ensuring the clones would serve the Sith's ultimate plan to destroy the Jedi Order and establish the Galactic Empire. The Kaminoans
column32: focused on the technical perfection of their work
column33: remained largely unaware of the larger conspiracy they were facilitating.\n\nTen years after the initial order
column34: Jedi Master Obi-Wan Kenobi arrived on Kamino while investigating the attempted assassination of Senator Padmé Amidala. The Kaminoans
column35: believing the Jedi had come to inspect the clone army
column36: welcomed him and revealed the massive military force they had created. This discovery led directly to the outbreak of the Clone Wars when the Grand Army of the Republic was deployed to rescue Jedi on Geonosis.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column37: Kamino became one of the Republic's most strategically important worlds. The planet's cloning facilities worked continuously to produce replacement troops for the Grand Army
column38: with new batches of clones constantly being grown
column39: trained
column40: and deployed to battlefronts across the galaxy. The Kaminoans took great pride in their work
column41: viewing each clone as a testament to their genetic expertise.\n\nThe Confederacy of Independent Systems recognized Kamino's importance and launched a major assault on the planet during the war. The Battle of Kamino saw massive droid forces
column42: including aquatic assault vehicles
column43: attacking Tipoca City in an attempt to destroy the Republic's ability to produce more clone troopers. Republic forces
column44: including clone troopers defending their homeworld
column45: successfully repelled the attack
column46: though the battle demonstrated Kamino's vulnerability.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire and the end of the Clone Wars
column47: Kamino's role began to change. The Empire continued to use Kaminoan cloning facilities initially
column48: but Emperor Palpatine grew concerned about relying on a single source for military personnel. The Empire began recruiting regular human soldiers and establishing training facilities on other worlds.\n\nThe Kaminoans' attempts to create a more independent clone force
column49: free from the inhibitor chips that ensured loyalty to the Empire
column50: led to increasing tensions with Imperial authorities. The Empire viewed any unauthorized cloning projects as potential threats to Imperial control.\n\nDuring the early years of the Galactic Civil War
column51: Imperial presence on Kamino remained significant
column52: though the planet's importance had diminished from its Clone Wars peak. Some cloning operations continued
column53: though on a much reduced scale compared to wartime production.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column54: Kamino's fate remained uncertain. The planet's cloning facilities
column56: had been greatly reduced from their wartime capacity. The Kaminoans continued their genetic research
column57: though their role in galactic affairs had diminished significantly from the days when their clone armies had shaped the fate of the entire galaxy."

Text: "Kashyyyk
column4: also known as Wookiee Planet C
column5: Edean
column7: and Wookiee World
column8: is a Mid Rim planet. It is the lush
column9: wroshyr tree-filled homeworld of the Wookiees."

Text: "Kashyyyk is a lush
column4: forested planet located in the Mytaranor sector of the Mid Rim Territories. The homeworld of the Wookiee species
column5: Kashyyyk is entirely covered by massive wroshyr trees that tower kilometers into the sky
column6: creating a unique multi-layered ecosystem. The planet's ecology is divided into distinct levels - from the dangerous Shadowlands at ground level where the most fearsome predators dwell
column7: through the middle levels where most Wookiees live
column8: to the uppermost canopy where the wroshyr trees reach toward the sky.\n\nThe Wookiees are a species of tall
column9: fur-covered humanoids known throughout the galaxy for their great strength
column10: mechanical aptitude
column11: and unwavering loyalty. Their culture emphasizes honor
column12: family bonds
column13: and the sacred concept of life debts - a Wookiee who is saved by another being will devote their life to serving and protecting their savior. Despite their fearsome appearance and warrior traditions
column14: Wookiees maintain a deep reverence for nature and live in harmony with their forest world
column15: building their tree cities without harming the ancient wroshyr trees.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column16: Kashyyyk was discovered by the Galactic Republic and became a member world. The Wookiees proved to be valuable members of galactic civilization
column17: with many leaving their homeworld to serve as mechanics
column18: pilots
column19: and warriors throughout the galaxy. Their technical skills and loyalty made them highly sought after
column20: though they never forgot their connection to their forest home.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column21: Kashyyyk remained steadfastly loyal to the Republic. Near the war's end
column22: the Confederacy of Independent Systems launched a major invasion of the planet
column23: recognizing its strategic importance and seeking to strike at the Republic's morale. The Battle of Kashyyyk saw intense fighting as Republic forces
column24: including Jedi Master Yoda
column25: worked alongside Wookiee warriors to defend the tree cities from droid armies.\n\nWhen Order 66 was executed during the battle
column26: clone troopers turned on their Jedi commanders. Master Yoda narrowly escaped with the help of Wookiee leaders Tarfful and Chewbacca
column27: who smuggled him off-world. This act of defiance would have severe consequences for the Wookiee people.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column28: Kashyyyk was brutally subjugated. The Empire enslaved the Wookiee population on a massive scale
column29: viewing them as little more than valuable labor. Imperial forces occupied the planet
column30: stripping its forests of resources while shipping Wookiees throughout the galaxy to work on Imperial projects. The construction of the Death Star relied heavily on Wookiee slave labor
column31: with thousands forced to work in brutal conditions.\n\nThe occupation of Kashyyyk was maintained by Imperial garrison forces and enforced through intimidation and violence. Any Wookiee resistance was met with overwhelming force

Text: "Kelada is a planet in the Anarid Cluster. It was controlled by the Galactic Empire during the Galactic Civil War."

Text: "Kessel is a planet within the Akkadese Maelstrom that host spice mines. The planet also export coaxium and Kesselstone. While Kessel's northern hemisphere is devoted to mining
column4: the planet's southern hemisphere is home to lush sanctuaries."

Text: "Kessel is a harsh planet located within the treacherous Akkadese Maelstrom in the Outer Rim Territories. The planet is infamous throughout the galaxy as the source of the highly valuable and addictive substance known as spice
column4: as well as coaxium and Kesselstone.\n\nKessel's northern hemisphere is dominated by extensive mining operations
column5: where prisoners and slaves labor in brutal conditions to extract spice from deep beneath the planet's surface. The spice mines of Kessel have become synonymous with the worst form of penal servitude
column6: with many criminals throughout the galaxy sentenced to hard labor in these deadly tunnels.\n\nThe planet's southern hemisphere contrasts sharply with the industrial north
column7: featuring lush gardens and sanctuaries maintained by the planet's administrators. These areas serve as retreats for those wealthy and powerful enough to afford such luxury
column8: while the vast majority of Kessel's population toils in the mines.\n\nKessel has changed hands numerous times throughout its history. During the Old Republic era
column9: the planet was controlled by various criminal organizations and corporate interests seeking to profit from its valuable resources. The Tion Hegemony once claimed Kessel before it fell into the hands of independent operators.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column10: Kessel remained largely outside the main conflict
column11: though both the Republic and Separatists sought to control its spice production. Following the rise of the Galactic Empire
column12: Imperial forces took control of Kessel
column13: using the planet as a prison world and continuing the brutal exploitation of its resources.\n\nThe Kessel Run
column14: a hyperspace route used by smugglers to transport spice from Kessel while avoiding Imperial patrols
column15: became one of the most famous - and dangerous - routes in the galaxy. Pilots who could complete the Run quickly earned considerable reputation among the smuggling community.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor
column16: control of Kessel remained contested between corporations and criminal organizations
column17: with various factions vying for control of the planet's valuable spice production."

column5: with a recorded history dating back to 10

Text: "Kinyen is an agriworld in the Expansion Region

column5: with a recorded history dating back to 10

Text: "The Kira system is a star system located in the Borderland Regions of the Outer Rim Territories

column9: forests

The asteroid fields that mark their former orbits serve as a reminder of the system's violent past and continue to attract treasure hunters and archaeologists seeking clues about what befell the lost planets."

Text: "Kubindi is a planet located in the galaxy's Outer Rim Territories that is the homeworld of the insectivorous Kubaz species."

Text: "Lannik is a planet with a long history of war that is located in the galaxy's Mid Rim that is the homeworld of the Lannik species."

Text: "Lianna is an astronomical object located in the Tion Cluster of the galaxy's Outer Rim Territories that was home to the powerful Santhe family."

Text: "Llanic is a planet located in the Llanic system within the galaxy's Outer Rim Territories. It is situated at the intersection of the Llanic Spice Route and the Triellus Trade Route."

column11: though it avoided becoming a major battlefield.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column12: Llanic fell under Imperial authority. The Empire maintained a presence on the planet to monitor trade traffic and collect customs revenues from the busy trade routes. Imperial oversight brought increased regulation to commerce passing through the system
column13: though Llanic's economy continued to benefit from its position as a major trade nexus.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column14: Llanic remained under Imperial control for most of the conflict. The planet's location made it strategically valuable to both the Empire and the Rebel Alliance
column15: though changing it hands during the war. After the Battle of Endor and the fragmentation of Imperial authority
column16: Llanic's status became contested as various Imperial remnant factions and the New Republic competed for control of key trade routes in the Outer Rim."

Text: "Loronar is an astronomical object located in the galaxy's Colonies region that is situated along the Corellian Run."
"Loronar is a terrestrial planet located in the Colonies region of the galaxy
column4: positioned along the Corellian Run hyperlane. A heavily industrialized world known for its advanced technology and manufacturing capabilities
column5: Loronar has been a significant producer of military and civilian equipment for millennia.\n\nThe planet is best known as the headquarters of Loronar Corporation
column6: one of the galaxy's major industrial conglomerates. The corporation specializes in military hardware
column7: including vehicles
column8: weapons systems
column9: and starship components
column10: establishing Loronar as a key supplier to various galactic governments throughout history.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column11: Loronar maintained steady economic growth through its industrial output and strategic position along the Corellian Run. The planet's factories and research facilities developed numerous innovations that found their way into military and civilian markets across the galaxy.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column12: Loronar remained loyal to the Galactic Republic
column13: with Loronar Corporation supplying military equipment to Republic forces. The planet's industrial capacity contributed significantly to the Republic's war effort
column14: producing vehicles and weapons systems for the Grand Army of the Republic.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column15: Loronar Corporation became a major Imperial contractor. The Empire made extensive use of the company's products
column16: with Loronar-manufactured equipment serving throughout the Imperial military. The planet's strategic importance and economic value ensured continued Imperial oversight and protection.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column17: Loronar remained firmly under Imperial control. The Empire maintained a strong presence on the planet to protect its vital industrial infrastructure and ensure continued production of military hardware. Loronar Corporation continued to develop new technologies and equipment for the Imperial war machine throughout this period.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the fragmentation of Imperial authority
column18: Loronar's status became contested as various Imperial remnant factions and the New Republic competed for control of strategic industrial worlds in the Colonies region."

Text: "Lorta is a Mid Rim world located on the Cerean Reach
column4: near Jiroch-Reslia. It is home to the violent and expansionist Lortans."

Text: "Lorta is a terrestrial planet located in the Mid Rim region of the galaxy
column4: positioned along the Cerean Reach hyperlane near Jiroch-Reslia. The homeworld of the Lortan species
column5: a humanoid race characterized by their aggressive and expansionist nature
column6: Lorta has been a source of regional instability for centuries.\n\nThe Lortans developed a militaristic culture that emphasized conquest and territorial expansion. Their society was organized around strict martial codes and hierarchical command structures
column7: with military service being mandatory for all able-bodied citizens. This warrior culture led the Lortans to repeatedly attempt expansion into neighboring systems
column8: bringing them into conflict with nearby civilizations.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column9: Lorta's aggressive policies made it a problematic world for the Galactic Republic to manage. The Lortans frequently engaged in border skirmishes with neighboring systems
column10: particularly targeting the peaceful Cerean civilization. The Republic was forced to maintain a significant peacekeeping presence in the region to prevent Lortan expansion from destabilizing the entire sector.\n\nThe Lortans' military ambitions were somewhat curtailed by their technological limitations and the Republic's diplomatic and military interventions. However
column11: their expansionist ideology remained deeply ingrained in Lortan society
column12: with each generation raised to believe in their species' manifest destiny to rule surrounding systems.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column13: Lorta remained nominally loyal to the Republic
column14: though their cooperation was often grudging. The Lortans saw the conflict as an opportunity to pursue their own territorial ambitions under the guise of supporting the Republic war effort
column15: leading to tensions with Republic command.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column16: Lorta came under Imperial control. The Empire initially found the Lortans' militaristic culture useful
column17: recruiting many into the Imperial military where their aggressive nature could be channeled toward Imperial objectives. However
column18: the Lortans' independent streak and desire for autonomy frequently brought them into conflict with Imperial authorities.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column19: Lorta remained under Imperial occupation
column20: though elements within Lortan society were divided. Some saw the Empire as a means to achieve their expansionist goals
column21: while others resented Imperial oversight and secretly sympathized with the Rebel Alliance. The planet's strategic location along the Cerean Reach made it valuable to both sides of the conflict.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column22: Lorta's status remained uncertain. The Lortans' aggressive reputation made neighboring systems wary of any potential resurgence of expansionist policies."

Text: "Lothal is a planet in the Outer Rim Territories. During the early years of the Galactic Empire
column4: Lothal was in a state of economic disrepair and invited the Empire to take over the planet's industries
column5: with the promise of prosperity and security."

Text: "Lothal is a terrestrial planet located in the Lothal system of the Outer Rim Territories
column4: positioned along the Corellian Trade Spine hyperlane. A world of grasslands
column5: farms
column6: and scattered urban centers
column7: Lothal remained largely isolated from galactic affairs for much of its history.\n\nThe planet's surface features wide plains perfect for agriculture
column8: with the capital city of Capital City serving as the primary spaceport and commercial hub. The native Loth-cats and Loth-wolves roam the grasslands
column9: while the sentient but primitive Loth-rats inhabit the wilderness areas.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column10: Lothal was discovered and lightly settled
column11: developing a modest agricultural economy. The planet maintained a quiet existence for millennia
column12: with most inhabitants living as farmers or working in small manufacturing facilities. Lothal's isolation meant it avoided much of the conflict that engulfed other worlds during various galactic wars.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column13: Lothal remained neutral and largely untouched by the conflict. The planet's distance from major battle zones and lack of strategic resources meant both the Republic and Separatists showed little interest in the world.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column14: Lothal's fate changed dramatically. The Empire recognized the planet's potential for industrial development and its strategic position along the Corellian Trade Spine. Imperial forces arrived on Lothal with promises of economic prosperity
column15: jobs
column16: and security. The planetary government
column17: facing economic difficulties
column18: welcomed the Imperial presence.\n\nThe Empire quickly established a significant presence on Lothal
column19: constructing factories
column20: refineries
column21: and military installations. Imperial industry began exploiting the planet's natural resources
column22: with strip mining and industrial pollution gradually degrading Lothal's once-pristine environment. The promised prosperity proved hollow for most Lothals
column23: as Imperial corporations paid minimal wages while environmental damage destroyed traditional farming livelihoods.\n\nCapital City grew rapidly under Imperial occupation
column24: with towering factories and Imperial architecture transforming the once-modest settlement into a sprawling industrial center. However
column25: the Old Jho's Pit Stop cantina and other local establishments remained as reminders of Lothal's pre-Imperial character.\n\nThe Empire established a major Imperial Academy on Lothal to train officers and stormtroopers. The facility became one of the more significant military training centers in the Outer Rim
column26: producing personnel for deployment throughout Imperial space.\n\nDuring the early years of the Galactic Civil War
column27: Lothal became a hotbed of resistance activity. A small group of rebels led by former Jedi Padawan Kanan Jarrus and his apprentice Ezra Bridger
column28: a native of Lothal
column29: began conducting operations against the Empire. Their actions
column30: including theft of Imperial supplies and the disruption of Imperial operations
column31: drew increasing Imperial attention to the planet.\n\nThe Empire responded to the growing rebellion by tightening security and deploying additional forces. Grand Moff Wilhuff Tarkin personally visited Lothal to oversee the suppression of rebel activity
column32: demonstrating the Empire's determination to maintain control of this strategically valuable world.\n\nThe rebels continued their resistance despite overwhelming Imperial presence
column33: becoming symbols of hope for Lothal's oppressed population. Their activities included rescuing Wookiee slaves
column34: disrupting Imperial supply lines
column35: and eventually making contact with the wider Rebel Alliance.\n\nImperial Mining operations on Lothal uncovered rare kyber crystals beneath the planet's surface. The Empire established extensive mining operations to extract these crystals for use in various Imperial projects
column36: further devastating Lothal's environment and displacing local communities.\n\nThe rebel cell on Lothal eventually joined forces with the larger Rebel Alliance
column37: escalating their operations against the Empire. Their activities drew the attention of some of the Empire's most dangerous agents
column38:
including the Inquisitorius and eventually Darth Vader himself.

The conflict on Lothal reached a climax when the rebels launched a major offensive to liberate the planet from Imperial control. The battle saw the destruction of the Imperial factories and the death of Grand Admiral Thrawn's forces being pulled into hyperspace along with Thrawn and Ezra Bridger during the confrontation.

Following the Empire's defeat at the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column39: Lothal began the long process of recovery. The planet worked to heal the environmental damage caused by years of Imperial exploitation and to rebuild its economy on more sustainable foundations. Former Imperial facilities were repurposed
column40: and the population slowly returned to their traditional ways of life while adapting to the new galactic order."

Text: "Lucazec is a planet located within the Outer Rim Territories. Originally known as Far Thanium
column4: it was absorbed into Xim's Empire as he expanded his borders from the Kingdom of Cron."

Text: "Lucazec is a terrestrial planet located in the Outer Rim Territories along the Salin Corridor hyperlane. Originally known as Far Thanium
column4: this world was absorbed into Xim the Despot's empire as he expanded his borders from the Kingdom of Cron during his reign approximately 25
column5: 000 years before the rise of the Galactic Empire.\n\nThe planet's surface features varied terrain suitable for habitation
column6: though it never developed into a major population center. Throughout much of galactic history
column7: Lucazec remained a relatively minor world
column8: overshadowed by more prominent systems along nearby trade routes.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column9: Lucazec maintained membership in the Galactic Republic
column10: serving primarily as a waypoint for travelers navigating the Salin Corridor. The planet's economy relied on modest agriculture and light manufacturing
column11: with most inhabitants living quiet lives far from the political intrigues of the Core Worlds.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column12: Lucazec remained loyal to the Republic
column13: though its remote location and limited strategic value meant it saw little direct involvement in the conflict. The planet continued its traditional way of life despite the surrounding galactic turmoil.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column14: Lucazec fell under Imperial authority. The Empire established a presence on the planet to maintain order and collect taxes
column15: though the garrison remained relatively small given the world's peripheral importance to Imperial interests.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column16: Lucazec remained under nominal Imperial oversight
column17: serving as a minor supply depot for Imperial forces operating in the Outer Rim. The planet's isolation from major conflict zones allowed it to avoid much of the devastation that befell other worlds during this turbulent period.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the fragmentation of Imperial authority
column18: Lucazec's status became uncertain as various Imperial remnant factions and corporations competed for influence throughout the Outer Rim territories. The planet's inhabitants continued their traditional way of life while adapting to the changing political landscape of the post-Imperial era."

Text: "Molavar is a backwater
column4: desert world in the Outer Rim Territories
column5: with a number of seedy spaceports and low-income moisture farms. It is inhabited by beings of various species
column6: but especially by the native Molavaran race."

Text: "Molavar is a remote desert planet located in the Outer Rim Territories' Sprauc sector. A harsh
column4: arid world with little surface water and sparse vegetation
column5: Molavar features numerous moisture farms scattered across its dusty landscape
column6: worked by hardy colonists seeking to extract what little water exists in the atmosphere.\n\nThe planet's surface is dominated by rocky terrain and sandy wastes
column7: with settlements concentrated around the few areas where moisture collection is most viable. Despite its inhospitable environment
column8: Molavar developed a modest population drawn by the promise of independence and freedom from the oversight of Core World governments.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column9: Molavar remained a largely ignored frontier world
column10: its remote location and lack of valuable resources keeping it off most galactic charts. The planet attracted settlers seeking to escape the complexities of civilized space
column11: establishing small communities that operated with minimal outside interference.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column12: Molavar's isolation spared it from the conflict between the Republic and the Separatists. The planet maintained its quiet existence
column13: with inhabitants focused on the daily struggle of survival in the desert rather than galactic politics.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column14: Molavar fell under nominal Imperial control
column15: though the Empire showed little interest in the barren world beyond ensuring basic compliance with Imperial law. The lack of strategic value or exploitable resources meant Imperial presence remained minimal
column16: with local authorities retaining considerable autonomy.\n\nThe planet became known as a haven for smugglers
column17: bounty hunters
column18: and others seeking to operate outside Imperial scrutiny. Its spaceports
column19: though small and often run-down
column20: served as waypoints for those traveling the lesser-known hyperspace routes of the Outer Rim. These facilities developed reputations as rough
column21: lawless places where questions were rarely asked and Imperial oversight was largely absent.\n\nThe native Molavaran species
column22: adapted to their planet's harsh conditions
column23: made up a significant portion of the population alongside human settlers and various other species drawn to the frontier lifestyle. The Molavarans' intimate knowledge of their world's environment made them valuable guides and traders for offworlders unfamiliar with the planet's dangers.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column24: Molavar remained under loose Imperial control
column25: though the planet's isolation and lack of strategic importance meant it saw little direct involvement in the larger conflict. The Empire maintained only the most basic garrison forces
column26: primarily to monitor traffic through the system's spaceports.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column27: Molavar continued its existence as a remote frontier world
column28: its inhabitants maintaining their independent spirit. The planet's spaceports remained active
column29: serving traders
column30: smugglers
column31: and travelers who preferred to operate away from the scrutiny of major governments."

Text: "Manaan is an aquatic planet in the Pyrshak system. It is home to the Selkath
column4: an amphibious species. The planet is completely covered in water and is the only known source of the medicinal substance kolto in the galaxy."

Text: "Manaan is an oceanic planet located in the Pyrshak system of the Inner Rim Territories. The entire surface of the world is covered by a vast
column4: seemingly endless ocean
column5: with no landmasses breaking the waves. Beneath the turbulent surface lies the true civilization of Manaan
column6: built on massive floating platforms and extending down into the ocean depths.\n\nThe planet is home to the Selkath
column7: an amphibious species perfectly adapted to their aquatic environment. The Selkath are known for their diplomatic neutrality and their careful guardianship of Manaan's most precious resource: kolto
column8: a powerful healing fluid with medicinal properties unmatched throughout the galaxy. For millennia
column9: Manaan remained the sole source of kolto
column10: making it one of the most strategically valuable planets in known space.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column11: during the Jedi Civil War
column12: Manaan became a focal point of conflict as both the Galactic Republic and Darth Revan's Sith Empire sought to secure kolto supplies for their war efforts. The Selkath government maintained strict neutrality
column13: allowing both sides to establish embassies in Ahto City
column14: the planet's capital
column15: while carefully regulating kolto harvesting to prevent ecological damage to the ocean and its native species
column16: including the massive firaxa sharks.\n\nThe kolto itself was produced by the progenitor
column17: an ancient creature dwelling in the depths of Manaan's ocean. The Selkath considered this creature sacred and built their entire civilization around sustainable harvesting of kolto while protecting the progenitor. This delicate balance made Manaan's neutrality crucial
column18: as any disruption to kolto production would have galaxy-wide consequences.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column19: Manaan remained an important medical supplier
column20: though the planet's influence waned somewhat after the discovery of bacta
column21: a more easily produced healing substance. However
column22: kolto retained certain advantages over bacta
column23: and Manaan continued to maintain its position as a valued neutral party in galactic affairs.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column24: Manaan maintained its traditional neutrality
column25: though both the Republic and the Confederacy of Independent Systems sought to secure favorable trade agreements for kolto. The Selkath government carefully balanced these competing interests while protecting their homeworld from becoming embroiled in the conflict.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column26: Manaan came under Imperial oversight. The Empire showed interest in controlling kolto production
column27: though the Selkath's careful management of their resources and the planet's relative isolation helped maintain some degree of autonomy. The Empire established a presence on Manaan but found that heavy-handed tactics risked disrupting the delicate ecological systems that produced kolto.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column28: both the Empire and the Rebel Alliance recognized Manaan's strategic importance as a medical supplier. The planet remained officially neutral
column29: though individual Selkath held varying sympathies. The Selkath government worked to preserve their independence and protect their ocean world from the conflicts that engulfed much of the galaxy.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the formation of the New Republic
column30: Manaan sought to establish new trade relationships while maintaining its traditional neutrality. The planet's unique position as a major kolto supplier ensured continued galactic interest
column31: even as bacta became more widespread. The Selkath remained committed to protecting their ocean home and the ancient progenitor that had sustained their civilization for thousands of years."

Text: "The Manda system is a star system located in the galaxy's Mid Rim region and contain Manda and Manda Prime."
"Manda is a terrestrial planet located in the Manda system of the Mid Rim region. A world of varied terrain including plains
column4: forests
column5: and mountain ranges
column6: Manda developed as a relatively minor agricultural and trading center due to its modest resources and remote location.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column7: Manda remained a quiet frontier world
column8: maintaining minimal contact with the broader galactic community. The planet's isolation kept it largely independent of Core Worlds politics
column9: with most inhabitants living simple lives focused on farming and local trade.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column10: Manda maintained neutrality
column11: avoiding entanglement in the conflict between the Republic and the Separatists. The planet's distance from major hyperspace routes and limited strategic value meant it saw little direct involvement in the war.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column12: Manda fell under nominal Imperial control
column13: though the Empire maintained only a minimal presence due to the planet's peripheral location and limited economic value. Local authorities retained considerable autonomy in managing day-to-day affairs.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column14: Manda remained under loose Imperial oversight
column15: serving as a minor waypoint for Imperial supply lines operating in the Mid Rim. The planet's isolation from major conflict zones allowed it to avoid much of the devastation that befell other worlds during this period.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the fragmentation of Imperial authority
column16: Manda's status became uncertain as various criminal and corporate factions competed for influence throughout the Mid Rim territories."

Text: "The Mandalore system
column4: also known as the Mandalorian system
column5: is a star system located in the Mandalore sector of the galaxy's Outer Rim Territories that contain the planet Mandalore
column6: homeworld of the Mandalorian people
column7: its moon of Concordia
column8: and the planet Kalevala."

Text: "Mandalore is a harsh
column4: desert planet located in the Mandalore system of the Outer Rim Territories. Once a lush and verdant world
column5: Mandalore was transformed into a barren wasteland following centuries of warfare and conflict. The planet's surface is dominated by vast deserts of white sand
column6: with scattered domed cities serving as the last refuges of civilization.\n\nThe homeworld of the Mandalorian people
column7: a proud warrior culture known throughout the galaxy for their martial prowess and distinctive armor
column8: Mandalore has a long and turbulent history. The ancient Mandalorians
column9: known as the Taung
column10: originally hailed from Coruscant before migrating to Mandalore thousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire. Over millennia
column11: the Mandalorians developed a unique culture centered on honor
column12: combat
column13: and clan loyalty.\n\nDuring the Mandalorian Wars
column14: approximately four thousand years before the rise of the Empire
column15: the Mandalorians launched a massive campaign of conquest across the Outer Rim under the leadership of Mandalore the Ultimate. This conflict ended with their defeat at the hands of the Jedi and the Republic at the Battle of Malachor V
column16: leading to centuries of decline for Mandalorian civilization.\n\nThe New Mandalorians
column17: a pacifist government led by Duchess Satine Kryze
column18: rose to power in the years before the Clone Wars
column19: attempting to move Mandalorian society away from its warrior past. The New Mandalorians established their capital in the domed city of Sundari
column20: built upon the planet's barren surface. This peaceful regime faced opposition from the Death Watch
column21: a terrorist organization seeking to restore the warrior traditions of old.\n\nDuring the Clone Wars
column22: Mandalore maintained official neutrality
column23: though the planet became embroiled in conflict when Death Watch
column24: with the secret backing of Count Dooku and the Separatists
column25: launched attacks against the New Mandalorian government. The criminal Shadow Collective
column26: led by the former Sith Lord Maul
column27: eventually conquered Mandalore by manipulating Death Watch's internal divisions.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column28: Mandalore fell under Imperial occupation. The Empire installed a puppet government and maintained a strong military presence to suppress any resistance. Saxon Clan
column29: collaborators with the Empire
column30: helped enforce Imperial rule over the reluctant Mandalorian population. Many Mandalorians
column31: including members of Clan Wren and other clans
column32: formed resistance movements to fight against Imperial occupation.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column33: Mandalore remained under Imperial control
column34: with the Empire using the planet's strategic location and the Mandalorians' reputation as warriors to their advantage. However
column35: resistance continued throughout this period
column36: with various Mandalorian clans working both openly and covertly against Imperial rule.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the Emperor's death
column37: Mandalore's status remained contested. Various Imperial remnant factions
column38: New Republic forces
column39: and independent Mandalorian clans competed for control of the planet and the right to determine its future. The ancient weapon known as the Darksaber
column40: a symbol of leadership among Mandalorians
column41: became a focal point in the struggle for power
column42: as whoever wielded it had a claim to rule Mandalore according to tradition.\n\nThe planet's moon
column43: Concordia
column44: once housed mining facilities but was abandoned after the resources were exhausted. Death Watch later used Concordia as a secret base for their operations before their attempt to overthrow the New Mandalorian government.\n\nDespite its harsh environment and troubled history
column45: Mandalore remains a symbol of resilience and warrior pride for Mandalorians scattered throughout the galaxy. Many Mandalorians living off-world maintain their cultural traditions and hope to one day see their homeworld restored to its former glory."

Text: "Mataou is a planet in the Outer Rim
column4: along the Corellian Trade Spine. Once controlled by the Hutts
column5: it had been abandoned by its former masters and become occupied by criminal groups and farmers of a native serpentine species. To the Empire
column6: Mataou was little more than a checkpoint onto another hyperlane."

Text: "Mataou is a terrestrial planet located in the Outer Rim Territories along the Corellian Trade Spine hyperlane. A world of varied terrain including plains
column4: forests
column5: and scattered settlements
column6: Mataou remained largely isolated from major galactic conflicts for much of its history.\n\nDuring the Old Republic era
column7: Mataou was discovered and settled
column8: though it never developed into a major population center. The planet's remote location and modest resources meant it attracted little attention from Core Worlds governments or major corporations.\n\nAt some point in its history
column9: Mataou fell under the control of the Hutt Cartel
column10: becoming part of the vast criminal empire that dominated much of the Outer Rim. However
column11: the Hutts eventually abandoned their operations on the planet
column12: leaving behind a power vacuum that was filled by various criminal organizations and independent settlers.\n\nThe native Sakiyan species
column13: a humanoid race known for their exceptional tracking abilities and keen senses
column14: established communities on Mataou. The planet also became home to human settlers and other species seeking opportunities on the frontier. These diverse groups coexisted in an uneasy balance
column15: with criminal syndicates operating alongside legitimate farming communities.\n\nThroughout the Clone Wars
column16: Mataou's isolation spared it from the conflict between the Republic and the Separatists. The planet maintained its status as a frontier world
column17: largely ignored by both sides of the galactic struggle.\n\nFollowing the rise of the Galactic Empire
column18: Mataou came under nominal Imperial control. The Empire established a presence on the planet primarily to monitor traffic along the Corellian Trade Spine and maintain order along this important trade route. However
column19: Imperial oversight remained limited
column20: and much of the planet continued to operate under the influence of local criminal organizations.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column21: Mataou remained under loose Imperial authority
column22: serving as a minor checkpoint and waypoint for vessels traveling the Corellian Trade Spine. The planet's lack of strategic military importance meant it avoided becoming a major battleground
column23: though it occasionally saw smugglers and Rebel sympathizers pass through its spaceports.\n\nAfter the Battle of Endor and the fragmentation of Imperial authority
column24: Mataou's status became uncertain as various criminal syndicates
column25: Imperial remnants
column26: and the New Republic competed for influence along the Corellian Trade Spine. The planet continued its existence as a frontier world
column27: with its inhabitants adapting to the changing political landscape of the post-Imperial era."

Text: "The Maw Cluster is a group of black holes located very close to each other.\nThe exact cause of several black holes being this close to each other was something of a mystery
column4: as it seemed to be unnatural. Some speculated about the possibility of these black holes being placed like this by Ancient races from billions of years ago
column5: but it has been revealed
column6: that it has been created by the Killiks
column7: as a prison for the 'metaphysical' entity Abeloth.\nThe close proximity of black holes make this environment dangerous
column8: and unnavigable via hyperspace."

Text: "The Maw Cluster is an extremely hazardous region of space consisting of a dense collection of black holes located in the Kessel sector of the Outer Rim Territories. The cluster contains numerous black holes in close proximity to each other
column4: creating a treacherous gravitational maze that has claimed countless ships throughout galactic history.\n\nThe exact origins of the Maw's unusual configuration remained a mystery for millennia. Some theorized that the cluster was a natural phenomenon
column5: while others speculated about ancient races deliberately arranging the black holes billions of years ago. The truth
column6: however
column7: was far stranger - the Maw was created by the Killiks as a prison for the dangerous Force entity known as Abeloth.\n\nDue to the extreme gravitational forces and unstable hyperspace routes caused by the black holes' proximity
column8: the Maw is virtually impossible to navigate safely through hyperspace. Only a few treacherous safe routes exist through the cluster
column9: known as the Maw's throat
column10: requiring exceptional piloting skill and detailed knowledge of the constantly shifting paths.\n\nThousands of years before the rise of the Galactic Empire
column11: the Maw remained largely unexplored and avoided by most spacers. Its dangerous reputation and remote location meant that few ventured into its depths
column12: and those who did rarely returned to tell the tale.\n\nDuring the Galactic Civil War
column13: the Empire discovered the Maw's potential as a secret research facility location. The Imperial Maw Installation was constructed deep within the cluster
column14: hidden from the rest of the galaxy by the black holes' natural concealment. Here
column15: some of the Empire's most classified weapons projects were developed
column16: including prototypes for the Death Star's superlaser and other experimental superweapons.\n\nFollowing the Battle of Endor and the Emperor's death
column17: the Maw Installation continued its research under the leadership of Admiral Daala
column18: who had been placed in command of the facility by Grand Moff Tarkin before his death. The installation remained operational and unknown to both the New Republic and Imperial remnant factions for several years after Endor.\n\nThe Maw's isolation made it an ideal location for secret operations
column19: though the constant danger posed by the black holes meant that even reaching the installation required navigating one of the few stable routes through the cluster
column20: and these routes were known only to select Imperial personnel."

Text: "Milagro is a planet in the Expansion Region. Located at the intersection of the Correllian Run and the Harrin Trade Corridor
column4: it is a prosperous trade and manufacturing world. It was first discovered in the early millennia of the Galactic Republic
column5: and colonised by Corellians. In the age of the Galactic Empire it hosted an Imperial garrison."

Text: "Milagro is a prosperous planet located in the Expansion Region of the galaxy
column4: positioned at the strategic intersection of the Corellian Run and the Harrin Trade Corridor. This convergence of two major hyperspace routes has made Milagro one of the most important commercial centers in the Expansion Region for thousands of years.\n\nThe planet's surface features varied terrain including plains
column5: forests
